questions.text: Which of the following is false about Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojna?

choices.text: It is for employees covered under the ESI scheme
Only employee is eligible for medical care
Should have contributed under the scheme for 3 or more years to be eligible

questions.solution:
Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojana: This scheme of Unemployment allowance was introduced by w.e.f. 01-04-2005. An Insured Person who becomes unemployed after being insured three or more years, due to closure of factory/establishment, retrenchment or permanent invalidity are entitled to:-

  • Unemployment Allowance equal to 50% of wage for a maximum period of up to Two Years.
  • Medical care for self and family from ESI Hospitals/Dispensaries during the period IP receives unemployment allowance.
  • Vocational Training provided for upgrading skills - Expenditure on fee/travelling allowance borne by ESIC

questions.text: Monospot test is done in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Monospot test (Paul-Bunnell test) is done to identify heterophile antibody in a case of infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: The long axis of the blades in forceps delivery should be aligned with the________________
questions.solution:
The long axis of the blades should be aligned with the occipitomental diameter for the perfect grasp of the head.

In this alignment, most of the blade lies over the lateral face and risk of injury is minimal. Improper blade placement can cause the blades to slip off and cause injury during traction.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: All are true regarding Caroli’s disease except?
questions.solution:
The presentation of Caroli’s disease may be with abdominal pain or sepsis and not ascites.

Caroli’s disease:

  • Caroli’s disease is congenital dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary tree.
  • This disease is often complicated by the presence of intrahepatic stone formation.
  • Patients can present with abdominal pain or sepsis.
  • Biliary stasis with stone formation can lead to biliary sepsis.
  • Malignant change in the ductal system can lead to cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: The ring shown in the image below is a ______________
questions.solution:
NuvaRing is a hormonal contraceptive that releases ethinyl estradiol and etonogestrel once inserted into the vagina. The hormones are absorbed through the vaginal epithelium.

The ring is inserted within 5 days of onset of menses and is removed after 3 weeks to allow withdrawal bleeding. After removal, a new ring can be inserted in a week.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Carbon dioxide has a greater alveolar diffusion coefficient than oxygen because _____________

choices.text: O2 has a lower molecular weight

questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide has a higher diffusion coefficient than oxygen because it is more soluble in water.

Note: The rate of diffusion in the respiratory membrane is almost exactly the same as that in water

The alveolar diffusion coefficient is directly proportional to the solubility of a substance in water and inversely proportional to the square root of its molecular weight. Though carbon dioxide has a higher molecular weight compared to oxygen, it’s solubility in water is much higher. As a result, its diffusion coefficient is 20 times that of oxygen.

questions.text: Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is activated by ________________
questions.solution:
Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS II) is activated by ATP and PRPP. It is inhibited by UTP. CTP and GTP have no effect on the enzyme.

Related Pearl: Regulators of Pyrimidine Synthesis

questions.text: Ureteral dilation seen in pregnancy is most commonly _______________
questions.solution:
The right-sided ureter above the pelvic brim is most commonly dilated in pregnancy. This is due to the following reasons.

  • The dextro-rotated uterus compresses the right ureter more
  • The right ureter might also be compressed by the right ovarian vein complex
  • The sigmoid colon cushions the left ureter and reduces compression

The part above the pelvic brim is involved because the uterus laterally displaces and compresses the ureters at the pelvic brim. Thus, intra-ureteric pressure rises above this level.

Besides compression, progesterone also contributes to ureteral dilatation.

Clinical relevance: Hydroureter and hydronephrosis are physiological changes in pregnancy. They appear in the 2nd trimester and resolve within 6-12 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: A patient demonstrating the use of a toothbrush at the level of the chest has ______.
questions.solution:
A patient demonstrating the use of a toothbrush at the level of the chest has apraxia.

Apraxia: Inability to perform a movement or task when asked despite having the desire and physical capability to carry it out.

Types of apraxia:

  1. Kinetic: Inability to execute fine acquired motor movement, lesion in the precentral cortex.
  2. Ideomotor: Fails to perform on command. Lesion in parietal lobe.
  3. Constructional: lnability to reproduce simple geometric figure by drawing. Lesion in pathway between occipital or parietal area.
  4. Ideational: Loss of ability to formulate ideational plan for the execution of complex act. Lesion in the dominant parietal lobe.

Confabulation is a phenomenon in which the patient fills in memory gaps with inaccurate information. Further investigating the statement made by the patients may reflect past experiences or bizarre, fantastic stories.  This fabrication of false information is not done on purpose.

Astrexis/Flapping tremor is a type of negative myoclonus characterized by irregular lapses of posture of various body parts.Mostly associated with hepatic encephalopathy.

Hemispatial neglect is the inability to report, respond, or orient to stimuli in one half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits.

questions.text: Primary cause of death in patients with Cushing's syndrome is ______.
questions.solution:
The primary cause of death in Cushing's syndrome is a cardiovascular disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis.

Cushing's syndrome:

Clinical Feature Mechanism
Obesity, moon facies, and accumulation of fat in the posterior neck and back (buffalo hump) Central pattern of adipose tissue deposition 
Decreased muscle mass and proximal limb weakness Atrophy of fast-twitch (type 2) myofibers
Hyperglycemia, glucosuria, and polydipsia (secondary diabetes) Induce gluconeogenesis and inhibit the uptake of glucose by cells

the skin is thin, fragile, and easily bruised; wound healing is poor and cutaneous striae are particularly common in the abdominal area.

The catabolic effects cause loss of collagen 

Development of osteoporosis and increased susceptibility to fractures

The catabolic effects cause loss of collagen and resorption of bones
increased susceptibility to a variety of infections Immune suppression
Hypertension permissive action of glucocorticoids on catecholamines
Several mental disturbances, including mood swings, depression, and frank psychosis, Action on central nervous system

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of rhabdomyolysis?
questions.solution:
Hypophosphatemia (not hyperphosphatemia) is a cause of rhabdomyolysis.

Note: Hyperphosphatemia is a manifestation of rhabdomyolysis due to the release of intracellular phosphate. It may mask the true depletion of body stores of phosphate in this case.

RHABDOMYOLYSIS

Causes:

  • Crush injury
  • Dyelectrolemia : hypophosphatemia
  • Infections: Most common is influenza virus
  • Drugs: Most common is statins
  • Prolonged seizures
  • Malignant hyperthermia
  • Heat stroke
  • Severe hypothyroidism

Laboratory abnormalities

  • Most important investigation is raised serum CK
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Metabolic acidosis

Treatment: Aggressive IV fluids and Forced alkaline diuresis

questions.text: Regarding palatoprints, all are true except?

choices.text: Palatal rugae are unique to each person
Palatoprints are located in posterior part of palate
Palatoprints do not change during growth

questions.solution:
Anterior part of the palate has rough raised ridges known as Palatoprints or palatal rugae.

Palatal rugae are irregular, asymmetric ridges of mucous membranes on the palate which are unique to each person and hence used as a method of identification.

Once formed, they do not undergo any changes during growth, remaining in the same position throughout a person's entire life.

The study of palatal rugae to establish identity is known as Rugoscopy/ Palatoscopy/ Palatoprints.

questions.text: Loading dose depends on:
questions.solution:
Loading dose depends on volume of distribution.

Loading Dose = Vol. of Distribution x Desired Steady-state plasma Concentration.

When the time to reach steady state is long, as it is for drugs with long half-lives, it may be desirable to administer a loading dose that promptly raises the concentration of drug in plasma to the target concentration.

The volume of distribution is the proportionality factor that relates the total amount of drug in the body to the concentration.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman  with twins undergoes first trimester screening. Which of the following is the marker of choice in detecting trisomy 21?
questions.solution:
In multifetal pregnancies, nuchal translucency is the marker of choice for Down’s syndrome during the first trimester.

β-HCG and PAPP-A values may be falsely normal as unaffected fetuses can normalize the serum levels of these markers.

Maternal serum alpha fetoprotein (MSAFP) is measured in the second trimester as part of the triple and quadruple screening tests.

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased
PAPPA decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased
  MSAFP decreased MSAFP decreased
    Serum inhibin increased

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presented with complaints of intense irritation, pain and insects crawling in his right ear canal. On examination of right ear, a black ant was found crawling inside. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Kill the insect by instilling oil

questions.solution:
Flying or crawling insects like mosquitoes, beetles, cockroaches or ants may enter the ear canal and cause intense irritation and pain.

No attempt should be made to catch them alive. First, the insect should be killed by instilling oil (a household remedy), spirit or chloroform water. Once killed, the insect can be removed by any of the methods described below:

  • Forceps removal
  • Syringing
  • Suction
  • Microscopic removal with special instruments

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who met with a road traffic accident is brought to the casualty in an unconscious state. On eye examination, the right pupil is constricted, whereas the left pupil is dilated and unresponsive to light. A CT scan reveals left subdural hematoma. What is the ocular sign called?
questions.solution:
Hutchinson's pupil is seen in raised intracranial pressure (ICP) secondary to space-occupying lesions. The raised ICP compresses the oculomotor nerve and causes pupillary changes. The pupil on the side of the space-occupying lesion is affected first. The changes progress through three stages.

Stage Ipsilateral pupil Mechanism Opposite pupil Mechanism
1 Constricted Oculomotor nerve irritation Normal -
2 Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis Constricted Oculomotor nerve irritation
3 Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis  Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis 

Stage 3 indicates that the ICP is very high. Immediate cerebral decompression should be done in such patients.

Other options:

  • In Marcus Gunn pupil, both direct and consensual light reflexes are blunted when light is shone in the affected eye. This is due to a relative afferent pupilary defect (RAPD) seen in optic nerve lesions and severe retinal diseases. It is tested by the swinging flashlight test.
  • Adie’s pupil is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic lesions of the oculomotor nerve. The affected pupil is larger, light reflex is sluggish, and near reflex is slow and tonic. The contralateral pupil is normal.
  • Wernicke’s heminanopic pupil is seen in lesions of the optic tract. Direct and consensual light reflexes are absent when light is shone on the temporal retina of the ipsilateral eye and nasal retina of the contralateral eye.

questions.text: A second-year postgraduate tells you to perform ABG of a patient. All of the following is true about performing ABG except

choices.text: Radial artery is the most preferred site
A different site should be chosen if modified Allen’s test is positive
Before performing ABG, the syringe should be flushed with 2ml of heparin
A normal pH, pCO2 and HCO3 levels may not indicate absence of acid base balance

questions.solution:
Different site is chosen if modified Allen's test is negative. (Abnormal)

Modified Allen's Test is used to test the adequacy of collateral blood flow to hand especially mandatory before radial artery cannulation and sometimes, before drawing blood for arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis.

Method:

It is performed by asking the patient to make a tight fist and then occluding the radial and ulnar arteries.

Then, the patient is asked to open the hand and the occlusion over the ulnar artery is released.

Interpretation: 

If the palm remains pale for more than 5-15 seconds, it indicates reduced ulnar collateral flow. - Modified Allen's test negative.

 

Note: 

  • Test positive in Allen's test indicates that the collateral blood flow is abnormal.
  • Test positive in modified Allen's test indicates that the collateral blood flow is normal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows scar formation following elective tracheostomy procedure.

It is identified by the fact that in elective tracheostomy, a horizontal skin crease incision is made 2.5 cm above the suprasternal notch.

On the other hand, a vertical incision is made in an emergency tracheostomy.

Formation of normal scar is the final step in the physiological process of wound healing. Whereas the abnormal healing process can result in hypertrophic scar or keloid.

Hence, the image best describes the physiological process following elective tracheostomy.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: The instrument used for the assessment of rectocele and cystocele is _______
questions.solution:
Sim's speculum is used for assessment of rectocele and cystocele.

The speculum is applied against the vaginal wall and slowly retracted out until a bulge appears, indicating cystocele or rectocele.  It can also be used for visualisation of the vaginal walls.

Cusco’s speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualisation of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.

Auvard speculum is used during vaginal hysterectomy. It retracts the posterior vaginal wall and has a weighted handle that makes it self-retaining.

The Veda-scope is a recently developed alternative to bivalve speculums. The instrument creates an air tight seal at the vaginal introitus and the vagina is inflated with filtered air. Following inflation, the vaginal walls can be examined and tests such as VIA VILI (Visual inspection with acetic acid and lugol’s iodine) and pap smear can be performed. It also allows for taking pictures with a camera and introducing a light source.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A young woman reports that she checks if the front door of her home is locked 10-15 times a day, which leads to poor performance at work. She mentions that if she tries to prevent herself from doing this, she feels extremely anxious. Which of the following is associated with a good prognosis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of obsessive compulsion disorder (OCD). The presence of precipitating events is associated with a good prognosis.

OCD is a disorder characterized by repetitive and intrusive thoughts, preoccupations, and repetitive behaviors that the person feels compelled to do. The feelings, ideas, sensations, and intrusive thoughts, are referred to as obsessions. Conscious repetitive behaviors are called compulsions.

Symptom patterns of OCD are:

  • Contamination - This is the most common pattern. Objects are thought to be contaminated, the patient washes them repeatedly or avoids touching them.
  • Pathological doubt - This is the second most common pattern. The patient presents with a doubt and a compulsion to check. For example, patients do multiple checks on whether the stove is turned off or the door is locked.
  • Intrusive thoughts - These patients have repetitive thoughts of sexual or aggressive acts without a compulsion.
  • Symmetry - This presents as a need to do tasks with precision or symmetry. This leads to slowing of their work. For example, taking hours to shave.

A good prognosis for OCD is associated with the following:

  • A good social and occupational adjustment
  • The presence of precipitating event
  • Episodic nature of symptoms.

The following are associated with a bad prognosis in OCD:

  • Present since childhood (option A)
  • Coexisting major depressive disorder (option C)
  • Acceptance of obsessions and compulsions
  • Bizarre compulsions and coexisting delusional beliefs
  • OCD that requires hospitalization
  • Personality disorder – especially schizotypal personality (option D)

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: All of the following are known to cause drug induced lupus except?
questions.solution:
Tacrolimus does not cause lupus.

Drugs causing lupus are

  • Procainamide
  • Hydralazine
  • Isoniazid
  • Chlorpromazine
  • D-penicillamine
  • Methyldopa
  • Quinidine
  • Inhibitors of interferon
  • Captopril
  • Antihyperlipidemic - Simvastatin, Lovastatin

Procainamide is the most frequent offender followed by hydralazine.

Renal and CNS involvement are rare. All patients have ANA and most have antibodies to histones.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding dark field examination for syphilis is incorrect?

choices.text: Helps in confirming syphilis with oral lesions
Should be visualized within 20 minutes of collection
Detection rate decreases within few hours after starting treatment

questions.solution:
Dark field microscopy should be performed in a case of genital lesions only as in oral lesion it is not possible to differentiate pathogenic from commensal spirochetes.

Treponemes disappear from lesions within a few hours after starting antibiotics.

questions.text: In the given image, the structure marked as D develops from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as D in the given image is the cerebellum, which develops from metencephalon.

The metencephalon is a part of rhombencephalon. It is characterized by basal and alar plates and forms two components: 

(a) the cerebellum, a coordination center for posture and movement, and

(b) the pons, the pathway for nerve fibers between the spinal cord and the cerebral and cerebellar cortices.

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is _____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Macintosh laryngoscopic blade. It is the most commonly used laryngoscopic blade for endotracheal intubation in adults.

Laryngoscopic blades can be

  • Curved blade, Macintosh
  • Straight blade, Miller

The Macintosh blade is preferred for adults, and the Miller blade for infants.

The advantage of a curved blade is that greater room is available for the passage and manipulation of an endotracheal tube.

questions.text: What is the risk factor of developing DM type 2 if both parents are diabetic?
questions.solution:
Risk factor of developing DM type 2 if both parents are diabetic is 40%.

Risk factor of developing DM type 2 if single parent is diabetic is 25%.

questions.text: Which of the following increases when false positivity of a test decreases?
questions.solution:
Specificity of a test increases when false positivity decreases.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 50-year-old renal transplant patient presented with difficulty in vision. The fundoscopy was done and is shown below. Which of the following is false about the pathogen causing the disease?

choices.text: It  can cause pneumonia in bone marrow transplant patients
Congenital infection can cause intrauterine growth retardation
Valganciclovir is the treatment of choice for the infection of eye
Serological assays are important for immunocompromised patients

questions.solution:
The given scenario of an immunocompromised patient (post-renal transplant) presenting with difficulty in vision and the fundoscopic image showing patchy areas of retinal necrosis with irregular borders and overlying retinal hemorrhages is suggestive of Cytomegalovirus retinitis. Serological assays are not informative in immunocompromised patients as they are unable to mount a strong enough immunological reaction to be detected by the serological tests.

CMV retinitis shows “pizza pie” or “scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance” or “cottage cheese” on fundus examination. It appears as an arcuate zone of retinitis with hemorrhages and optic disc swelling. Often CMV is confined to the retinal periphery, beyond the view of the direct ophthalmoscope. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA) shows marked vascular sheathing. Cataract is a finding in the late stage of the disease.

Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management in the case of AIDS patients, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is taken orally and Ganciclovir is used as a slow-release intravitreal implant (Option C).

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in immunocompromised patients like bone marrow transplant recipients can lead to conditions like pneumonia, colitis, retinitis, or disseminated infection (Option A). Congenital infection can lead to features of intrauterine growth retardation, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, microcephaly, and retinitis in the baby (Option B).

Screening is done in patients with low CD4 counts once in 3 months if <50/μL, once in 6 months if 50–100/μL, and once a year, if >100/μL. The PCR assay is the gold standard for diagnosis.

questions.text: Propionate enters the TCA cycle as __________________
questions.solution: Propionate (3C) enters the TCA cycle as Succinyl CoA (4C) after undergoing carboxylation and isomerization.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic procedure has highest typical effective dose exposure?
questions.solution:
Typical effective dose of barium enema is 7mSv, which is the highest among the given options.

Other options:

  • Barium meal: 3mSv
  • Intravenous urography: 2.5mSv
  • CT head: 2.3mSV

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with loin pain. Urine examination shows 120rbc/hpf. Urine microscopy revealed dysmorphic RBCs in urine. The site of origin is _______.
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario, the most likely origin is kidney.

Dysmorphic hematuria is typical of glomerulonephritis.

When the source of hematuria is the kidney, RBCs pass through the tubule and hence deformed.

The presence of eumorphic RBCs in urine indicate that the source of bleeding is below the pelvis.

Causes of hematuria

  • Renal 
  • Systemic

Renal causes can be glomerular and non-glomerular

Glomerular Non-glomerular
Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abnormal shape and size) Isomorphic RBCs seen [ normal shape and size]
Rbc casts may be present Rbc casts always absent 
Mcv is small [ <72 fl] Mcv is normal
Protein leakage is more ( >1g/day) Protein leakage is less (<1g/day)
Cause is usually medical Cause is usally surgical

questions.text: Which of the following has a score of 2 in Alvarado scoring system?
questions.solution:
In the Alvarado scoring system, tenderness in right iliac fossa and leukocytosis ≥10⨯109 cells/L have two points.

Related Pearl: Alvarado Scoring System

Findings

Points

Migratory right iliac fossa pain

1

Anorexia

1

Nausea / vomiting

1

Tenderness in right iiliac fossa

2

Rebound tenderness right iliac fossa

1

Elevated temperature ≥ 37.3°C

1

Leukocytosis ≥ 10⨯109 cells/L

2

Shift to the left of neutrophils

1

 

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: The following histological image shows __________.
questions.solution:
The histological image shows fibrinoid necrosis in an artery.

The wall of the artery shows a circumferential bright pink area of necrosis along with protein deposition and inflammation.

It usually occurs in a case of immune reaction where complexes of antigens and antibodies are deposited in the walls of blood vessels, but may also occur in severe hypertension.

Conditions in which fibrinoid necrosis is seen: 

  • Polyarteritis nodosa 
  • SLE 
  • Serum sickness

questions.text: The half-life of Iodine-131 is ________
questions.solution:
The half-life of Iodine-131 is 8 days.

Iodine 131 is used for destruction of thyroid tissues due to the production of beta rays. Iodine 123 has only gamma activity and is used as a nuclear imaging tracer.

Half-lives of other radioactive iodine:

  • Iodine 123 has a half-life of 13 hours
  • Iodine 125 has a half-life of 60 days
  • Iodine 124 has a half-life of 4.18 days

questions.text: The maximum dose of plain lidocaine that can be given to a 70 kg male patient  is
questions.solution:
The maximum dose of plain lidocaine is 4.5 mg/kg, i.e., approximately 300 mg (in a 70 kg patient).

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD with fever, running nose, cough, and redness of the eyes. On examination, rash and bluish-white ulcerations are seen on the buccal mucosa. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

choices.text: Patients are contagious both during prodromal period and initial days of rash
Most common complication is otitis media
Involvement of central nervous system is uncommon

questions.solution:
Based on the symptoms and classic Koplik spots (small, bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower molars), the diagnosis is measles. 

Involvement of the CNS is common in measles such as encephalitis.

questions.text: A patient who was started on penicillamine subsequently presented with facial swelling. Urinalysis shows proteinuria. Histological image of the kidney biopsy is shown below. What will be the finding on immunofluorescence?

choices.text: Granular deposits of IgG along the basement membrane
Deposition of IgA in mesangial regions

questions.solution:
The above histological image shows the presence of uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. This image along with the clinical scenario of nephrotic syndrome depicts membranous nephropathy. Immunofluorescence, in this case, will show granular deposits of IgG along the basement membrane. 

Almost 75% of membranous nephropathy is primary and the rest is due to

  • Drugs such as penicillamine, captopril, gold, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
  • Malignant tumors of the lung and colon
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Infections such as chronic hepatitis B, hepatitis C, syphilis
  • Autoimmune disorders such as thyroiditis

Other options:

Option B: Linear deposition of antibodies(IgG) is seen in anti-GBM antibody disease.

Option C: Deposition of IgA in mesangial regions is seen in IgA nephropathy.

Option D: Effacement of the foot process is found in the electron microscopy picture of membranous nephropathy and minimal change disease.

questions.text: Which of the following about cefepime is true?

choices.text: It is not active against pseudomonas

questions.solution:
Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin.

  • It is more stable against plasmid-mediated beta-lactamase.
  • It is active against Staphylococcus aureus, Enterobacter, and Citrobacter.
  • It possesses anti-pseudomonal activity comparable to that of ceftazidime and gram-positive activity similar to that of ceftriaxone.
  • All cephalosporins, except cefoperazone and ceftriaxone, are eliminated primarily by the kidneys; thus, dose adjustment is required in renal insufficiency.
  • Cefepime has a short t1/2 (2 hours) and needs to be given 8 hourly.

questions.text: Total autonomic denervation of the heart causes _____________
questions.solution:
Total autonomic denervation of the heart causes increased heart rate.

This is because the resting vagal tone is greater than the sympathetic tone. The predominant vagal influence is removed on total autonomic denervation.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are resected in hepatic flexure cancer?

choices.text: A, B, C, D, E, F
A, B, C, D, E, F, G
A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H

questions.solution:
In the given image, A, B, C, D, E, F, G represents the terminal 10 cm of ileum, the right colon, and proximal transverse colon, which are resected in hepatic flexure cancer.

An extended right colectomy is preferred for curative-intent resection of lesions located at the hepatic flexure or proximal transverse colon.

Extended right colectomy:

  • The ileocolic vessels, right colic vessels, and middle colic vessels (at the base) are ligated and divided.
  • Approximately 10 cm of terminal ileum, the right colon, and proximal transverse colon are resected, and a primary anastomosis is created between the distal ileum and distal transverse colon.
  • Such an anastomosis relies on the marginal artery of Drummond.

questions.text: According to the ACOG, consecutive clomiphene citrate therapy should not exceed ___________
questions.solution: The ACOG recommends that clomiphene citrate should not be used consecutively for more than 6 months at a time. It also recommends that lifetime therapy should not exceed 1 year. This is because of the probable link between prolonged clomiphene citrate use and ovarian cancer.

questions.text: Damage to the anterior white commissure in the spinal cord causes ___________

choices.text: Loss of fine touch, pressure and proprioception

questions.solution:
Bilateral loss of pain and temperature is seen in anterior white commissure lesions. This area contains decussating fibers of the lateral spinothalamic tract carrying pain and temperature sensations.

Involvement of the anterior white commissure is classically seen early in central cord syndrome caused by syringomyelia, intrinsic cord tumors, and spinal trauma.

Other options:

All of these are late changes seen in central cord syndrome.

  • Loss of fine touch, pressure, vibration sense, and proprioception are due to posterior column involvement.
  • Atrophy of muscles is due to the involvement of the anterior horn.
  • Autonomic dysfunction arises due to involvement of the intermediolateral column.

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against ________.
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice for treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including Candida glabrata and Candida krusei), Scedosporium, and Fusarium.

Mucormycosis is treated with Amphotericin B. Posaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles are not effective against this fungus.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Hepatitis B?

choices.text: HBsAg prevalence ≥8% defines highly endemic area
Vaccine should be given within 24 hours after birth to prevent perinatal transmission
The median incubation period is less than 100 days.
Anti HBs and Anti HBc means vaccination is successful

questions.solution:
In the case of a successful vaccination, only anti-HBs is positive. In the case of recovery from hepatitis B, both anti-HBs and anti-HBc are positive. 

The hepatitis B vaccine can be monovalent or be combined as fixed-dose combinations with other vaccines like DPT, Hib, hepatitis A, and inactivated polio. A four-dose schedule is used in India where the first dose at birth is followed by three additional doses at 6, 10 and 14 weeks along with DPT vaccination. The minimum recommended interval between each dose of vaccine is four weeks. Longer dose intervals may increase the final anti-HBs titres but not the rate of sero-conversion. 

For newborns, it's recommended to use only the monovalent hepatitis B vaccine and it should be given within 24 hours after birth to prevent any perinatal transmission ( Option B )in countries of high prevalence. The complete vaccine series induces protective antibody levels in more than 95 per cent of infants, children and young adults.  The duration of protection is at least 15 years to life long. In any age group, interruption of the vaccination schedule does not require restarting of the vaccine series.

HBIG is used for those acutely exposed to HBsAg-positive blood for immediate protection. The recommended dose is 0.05 to 0.07 ml/kg of body weight, with two doses given 30 days apart. HBIG offers short-term protection for about 3 months. Since the incubation period is typically less than 100 days, ( Option C ) two doses of HBIG, spaced one month apart, should be enough.

questions.text: The vaginal vault is suspended from the anterior longitudinal ligament in ______________
questions.solution:
Sacral colpopexy involves suspending the vaginal vault from the anterior longitudinal ligament in front of the sacral promontory. The suspension is done using a Gore-Tex or Mersilene mesh and non-absorbable sutures. This is considered the gold standard treatment for vaginal vault prolapse after hysterectomy.

In sacrospinous colpopexy, the vault is fixed to the sacrospinous ligament on the right side. A special needle called Miya hook is used in the fixation.

In colpocleisis, the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are sutured from above downwards with absorbable purse string sutures. This is done in women who are not interested in retaining sexual function.

Le Fort’s repair is done in old women medically unfit to undergo hysterectomy for uterine prolapse. In this operation, a rectangular area is denuded in the anterior and posterior vaginal walls and sutured together with chromic catgut. This leaves a channel on either side for drainage of secretions.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should be excluded in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome?
questions.solution:
Verapamil, digoxin, beta-blockers are avoided in patients with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome.

Verapamil is contraindicated in these patients because it increases the refractoriness of the AV node with minimal or no effect on the accessory pathway. This can lead to faster ventricular rates, increasing the risk of ventricular fibrillation.

WPW syndrome is a congenital condition involving the presence of an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria and ventricles.

Procainamide and Class III- Ibutilide antiarrhythmic agents are the drugs of choice in wide complex tachycardias involving accessory pathways.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female presented with pain in neck, fever, malaise and firm enlargement of both lobes of the thyroid after a few days following viral fever. On investigation, thyroid antibodies were normal and serum T4 was slightly raised. The probable diagnosis is __________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of history of viral infection, pain in the neck, and bilateral enlargement of the thyroid lobes suggests a diagnosis of granulomatous thyroiditis (subacute/de Quervain’s thyroiditis).

Granulomatous thyroiditis may follow a viral infection. In a typical subacute presentation, there is pain in the neck, fever, malaise, as well as firm and irregular enlargement of one or both lobes of the thyroid.

There may be raised inflammatory markers, absent thyroid antibodies, serum T4 may be high normal or slightly raised and I123 uptake of the gland is low.

The specific treatment for acute case with severe pain is to give prednisone 10-20 mg daily for 7 days and to gradually taper over the next month. If thyroid failure is prominent, treatment with thyroxine may be required until function recovers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about clostridium species is true?

choices.text: Tetanus toxin acts on stimulatory neurons
Botulinum toxin acts by activating the SNARE protein
All species of clostridium are anerobic and can’t survive with ambient air
Most species are motile and possess peritrichous flagella

questions.solution:
Most species of clostridia are motile and possess peritrichous flagella.

Other options:

  • Tetanus toxin initially binds to receptors on the presynaptic membranes of motor neurons and migrates to the spinal cord and brainstem. The toxin diﬀuses to inhibitory neurons (γ-aminobutyric acid) from the brainstem and inhibits its function.
  • Botulinum toxin acts by cleavage of the SNARE protein, resulting in inhibition of Ach release causing paralysis.
  • While mostly they are anaerobes, a few species are aerotolerant and also grow in ambient air.

 

The following image shows Clostridium difficile with peritrichous (all over its body) flagella:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common form of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Clear cell carcinoma is the most common renal cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a sudden loss of vision in both eyes that occurred after a stressful argument with her boss. On examination, her visual acuity is recorded as 6/6 in each eye, and her pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. There are no abnormalities found on ophthalmic examination or in other neurological evaluations. When asked to follow a moving object or identify visual stimuli, she demonstrates inconsistent performance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is conversion disorder /functional neurologic symptom disorder.

Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced and the gain obtained is primarily psychological. 

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. Anaesthesia and paresthesia of the extremities, abnormal movements, and gait disturbance are the other features commonly seen. 

Conversion disorder usually resolves spontaneously. Insight-oriented or behavioural therapy is also helpful. Hypnosis and anxiolytics are used in some cases. 

Other options: 

Option B: Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. Some clinical features include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing.

Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), especially in its ischemic form, usually presents with severe visual loss, marked retinal haemorrhages, cotton wool spots, optic disc oedema, and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), often accompanied by detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic examination. However, this patient has normal visual acuity, normal pupillary reactions, and no detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic or neurological exams, making CRVO an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Option D: Eales' disease, common in young Asian males, features recurrent vitreous haemorrhage and retinal neovascularization due to peripheral retinal vein inflammation. It presents with a reddish vitreous mass and can lead to vision loss and complications like retinal detachment. However, it is less likely here due to the patient’s demographics and absence of characteristic findings.

Related Pearl: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment like mutism or blindness
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Primary gain - Unconscious relief from stress as the focus of the patient shifts to the symptoms.
  • Secondary gain - Attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of the symptoms.
  • La-belle indifference - refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability
  • Astasia abasia - Wildly ataxic, staggering gait accompanied by irregular, jerky truncal movements, thrashing and waving arm movements

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

Related Pearl: Somatoform Disorder

Somatoform Disorder

Key features of somatic symptom and related disorders

Somatic symptom disorder

Excessive anxiety and preoccupation with ≥1 unexplained symptom

Illness anxiety disorder

(hypochondriasis)

Fear of having a serious illness despite few or no symptoms and consistently negative evaluations

Conversion disorder

(functional neurologic symptom disorder)

Neurologic symptom  incompatible with any known neurologic disease, often acute onset associated with stress

Factitious disorder

Intentional falsification or inducement of symptoms with a goal to assume the sick role

Malingering

Falsification or exaggeration of symptoms to obtain external incentives (secondary gain)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Acute HIV syndrome?

choices.text: Fulminant infections are seen with 50% of the cases

questions.solution:
Fulminant course is seen in 10% of the cases.

Acute HIV syndrome is characterized by wide virus dissemination and seeding of lymphoid organs (e.g., Gut-associated lymphoid tissue), culminating in the destruction of CD4+ cells. The virus is transmissible during this early infection period.

The syndrome is typical of an acute viral syndrome and has been likened to acute infectious mononucleosis. The clinical findings include fever, lymphadenopathy, rash, pharyngitis, headache, arthralgia and anorexia/weight loss can also be seen.

Opportunistic infections can occur (rare) during this stage of infection, reflecting the immunodeficiency that results from reduced numbers of CD4+T cells.

questions.text: Which of the following scales is not used to classify socioeconomic status?
questions.solution: Likert scale is a psychometric scale used to understand people’s attitudes from responses. It is widely used in questionnaire-based research.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with 5 months of amenorrhea and pregnancy was confirmed by UPT. USG reveals a fetal cephalic index of 95 with a rounded head. Which of the following fetal parameters would you prefer to assess the gestational age?
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, head circumference is the best parameter to assess gestational age.

The cephalic index is defined as the ratio of the biparietal diameter to the occipitofrontal diameter and has a normal value between 70-86 depending on the gestational age. Here, the cephalic index is increased and the head is rounded, indicating brachycephaly. Though biparietal diameter is the best parameter to estimate gestational age in the 2nd trimester, it is not accurate in abnormal head shapes. Hence, head circumference is used as an alternative. It can also be used as an alternative to biparietal diameter in dolichocephaly where the cephalic index is reduced and the head is flattened.

Other options:

  • Crown-rump length is the best parameter in the 1st trimester; It is accurate to within 5-7 days.
  • Brachycephaly is associated with down’s syndrome in which the femur is short and hence; femur length measurement may not be reliable. Otherwise, femur length is the best parameter in the 3rd trimester and is accurate to within 7-11 days.

questions.text: A boy says he hates chocolates after his parents scolded him for eating too much of it. The defence mechanism operating here is  _______________
questions.solution:
Reaction formation is the defense mechanism operating here.

Reaction formation converts unacceptable impulses into acceptable ones before they enter consciousness. Here, the unacceptable impulse is the boy’s fondness for chocolate, which is turned into dislike to appease his parents.

Suppression is the conscious act of avoiding unpleasant thoughts and impulses. For example, a student trying to avoid thoughts about exams.

Asceticism means giving up on life’s pleasures. The person derives gratification from giving up pleasures. For example, a rich man giving away everything he owns and going on a pilgrimage.

Repression is the process of expelling and withholding a particular idea or a feeling from conscious awareness. This can be of two types:

  • Primary repression - When the feeling or idea is curbed before reaching consciousness
  • Secondary repression - When the feeling or idea which was once experienced is excluded from awareness.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Decreased HC/AC ratio is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Decreased HC/AC ratio is seen at term in fetal macrosomia, especially if the mother is diabetic. In macrosomia, the abdominal circumference increases disproportionately, and hence, HC/AC ratio decreases progressively until term.

Symmetric IUGR has a normal HC/AC ratio as fetal growth is proportionately reduced.

The HC/AC ratio is increased in asymmetric IUGR due to the brain sparing effect.

HC/AC ratio is also increased in hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A newborn on examination was found to have deafness, cataract and ventricular septal defect. Which of the following is false about the pathogen causing this syndrome?

choices.text: Both postnatally and congenitally acquired infection can become carriers
The infected person can transmit infection from one week before the onset of rashes
It has one of the most effective vaccine available as seroconversion is more than 95%

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is classic for congenital rubella syndrome (deafness, cataract, and cardiac defects).

Only congenitally acquired infection can turn into a carrier state.

Other options are correct.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Idiopathic degeneration of proximal bundle branch fibers is known as _________.
questions.solution:
Lenegre’s disease is idiopathic degeneration of proximal bundle branch fibres.

Lev's disease is an acquired complete heart block due to idiopathic fibrosis and calcification of the electrical conduction system of the heart.

Ashman phenomenon is an aberrant ventricular conduction due to a change in QRS cycle length.

Brugada Syndrome:

  • Sodium channelopathy
  • High risk of arrhythmias
  • Sudden cardiac death
  • ICD is the device of choice

ECG in Brugada Syndrome:

  • Coved ST segment elevation of V1-V3 followed by a negative T wave is the only ECG abnormality that is potentially diagnostic. This has been referred to as Brugada sign.

questions.text: Urinary bladder can be injured in all the following operations, except _______.
questions.solution:
Urinary bladder injury is not commonly associated with inguinal lymph node dissection.

The urinary bladder may be injured in

  1. Inguinal or femoral herniotomy
  2. Hysterectomy
  3. Excision of the rectum

If the injury is recognized, the bladder must be repaired and catheter drainage maintained for 7 days.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with fever, ear-ache. On examination, tympanic-membrane appears congested and bulging with loss of landmarks. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Fever, earache, congested and bulging tympanic membrane in a 4-year-old child points towards a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM).

Antibiotics form the mainstay of treatment in acute suppurative otitis media, and once the tympanic membrane is seen bulging, myringotomy should be done. 

Myringotomy is indicated only when there is an impending rupture of tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding nabothian cysts.
questions.solution:
Nabothian cysts are benign retention cysts and are not pre-malignant. They form when squamous epithelium from the ectocervix covers the opening of endocervical mucus glands and mucus accumulates within the glands.

The cysts are usually seen in chronic cervicitis where the squamous epithelium spreads to the endocervix due to repeated inflammation and healing. Most of the cysts are in the submucosal layer.

If the cysts grow large, they can cover the cervical os and cause irregular bleeding. They can also cause watery discharge per vaginum.

Symptomatic cysts can be treated with excision, cryo-cautery, or electrocautery. Hysterectomy may be rarely needed if there are multiple or very large cysts.

questions.text: Right-handed alpha helices in proteins are made up of ________________

choices.text: Either L or D amino acids
Both L and D amino acids

questions.solution:
All proteins and polypeptides, including right-handed alpha helices, are made up of only L-amino acids.

Most of the naturally occurring monosaccharides are D sugars.

questions.text: While examining the oral cavity of a patient with lichen planus. you notice the following lesion. Which of the following describes the lesion best?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Wickham striae, which are whitish lines visible in the papules of oral lichen planus a condition reclassified as pre-malignant in the WHO digital manual for the early diagnosis of oral neoplasia.

Clinically, oral lichen planus can present as Wickham striae, white papules, white plaque, erythema, erosion, or blisters. They may be symmetrical and bilateral. Buccal mucosa, dorsum of the tongue, and gingivae are commonly affected. Early diagnosis and management play an important role in the prevention of progression to malignancy. The management involves:

  • Maintenance of good oral hygiene
  • Elimination of precipitating factors
  • Topical steroids
  • Topical isotretinoin gel & tretinoin ointment

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. It is a chronic disease with a number of relapses and remissions.

Various factors can precipitate the disease like:

  • Viruses like: Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human herpes viruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), Varicella zoster
  • HLA-A3, HLA-5 association
  • Environmental factors like:
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 P"s of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

Complications of lichen planus includes:

  • Hair: Patches of cicatricial scarring alopecia
  • Nails: Various nail changes are seen associated with lichen planus. 
    • Dorsal Nail Pterygium: Most specific nail change in lichen planus where the fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium formation.
    • Thinning of the nail plate: Most common nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions.
    • Pup-tent sign: Elevation of nail in the shape of a tent
    • Trachonychia: All 20 nails of hands and feet undergo dystrophy
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
    • Longitudinal melanonychia in lichen planus of the nail bed
    • Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)
  • Mucous membranes: Squamous cell carcinoma may occur on the lip, buccal mucosa or gum margin
 

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

questions.text: Total fetal cardiac output is _____ mL/kg/minute.
questions.solution:
Total fetal cardiac output is 450 mL/kg/minute.

Approximately 65% of the descending aortic blood flow returns to the placenta; the remaining 35% perfuses the fetal organs and tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following mutations is uncommon in a case of lung cancer in a non-smoker?
questions.solution:
KRAS mutation is uncommon in a case of lung cancer in a non-smoker.

EGFR is the most common mutation in a case of lung cancer in a non-smoker, followed by TP53.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is false regarding the lesions shown in the given image?

1. It is a localized cutaneous disorder.
2. It is also known as actinic keratoses.
3. Associated with underlying lung and GI malignancy.
4. It is a malignant epidermal tumor.
questions.solution:
The image shows seborrheic keratoses. The false statements are 2 and 4.

Seborrheic keratoses are benign localized cutaneous multiple eruptive lesions over the back, abdomen, and neck (statements 1 and 4). This acute onset of an increase in size and number of seborrheic keratoses is a sign of internal malignancy called the sign of Leser-Trélat. 

When it is associated with pruritus or acanthosis nigricans, especially in younger patients, it warrants investigation for internal malignancy. About 1/3rd of associated tumors are in the gastrointestinal tract, and about half of these tumors are adenocarcinomas (statement 3).

Actinic keratoses are hyperkeratotic pre-malignant lesions caused by chronic exposure to sunlight which may progress to squamous cell carcinoma. (statement 2)

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

questions.text: Which of the following is helpful in predicting the virulence of a disease?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is linked to the killer power or virulence of a disease.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with a history of serous discharge from an external opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. Where is the location of the internal opening likely to be?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a fistula-in-ano. Here, the external opening was at 8'O clock which is considered posterior. According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline (6’O clock position). Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at 6’O clock position.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the internal posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

questions.text: Tuberculous pleural effusion is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Tuberculous pleural effusion is characterized by all the above-mentioned features except for high mesothelial cell count. 

Mesothelial cells are the cells that line the pleural membranes. Their count is increased in pleural fluid usually in transudative effusions. Tuberculous effusion is exudative, mesothelial cells are not increased in this condition.

Tuberculous pleural effusion is an exudative pleural effusion. It is caused due to hypersensitivity to tuberculous proteins.

Pleural fluid in tuberculosis has a high protein concentration (>50 %), normal to low glucose concentration, pH ~7.3, and detectable white blood cells. It is usually straw-colored but can be hemorrhagic in some cases. Exudative effusions like the tuberculous effusion have a pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio of >0.6.

Pleural fluid has increased levels of TB markers such as adenosine deaminase (> 40 IU/L) and interferon γ (> 140 pg/mL).

 

The illustration below shows the steps involved in the insertion of the chest drain which is used for the management of various pleural effusions.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: Mitral cells are present in:
questions.solution:
Mitral cells are seen in the olfactory bulb.

Axons of olfactory nerves (first cranial nerve) synapse with the mitral cells and tufted cells in the olfactory bulb to form anatomically discrete units called olfactory glomeruli.

These mitral and tufted cells (second-order neurons) terminate in the olfactory cortex.

The olfactory bulb also contains periglomerular cells that are inhibitory interneurons and granule cells that make reciprocal synapses with mitral and tufted cells.

The five regions of the olfactory cortex:

  • Anterior olfactory nucleus
  • Olfactory tubercle
  • Piriform cortex
  • Amygdala: pathway concerned with emotional responses to olfactory stimuli
  • Entorhinal cortex: pathway concerned with olfactory memories

From all the five regions information travels directly to the frontal cortex or via the thalamus to the orbitofrontal cortex. This pathway is concerned with conscious discrimination of odors.

questions.text: All of the following are minimum standards for monitoring of a patient in shock except?
questions.solution:
Central venous pressure does not come under the minimum standard for monitoring of a patient in shock. It is one of the additional modalities to be done in shock patients.

The minimum standard modalities for monitoring patients in shock are

  • ECG
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Blood pressure
  • Urine output

The additional modalities are

  • Central venous pressure
  • Invasive blood pressure
  • Cardiac output
  • Base deficit and serum lactate

Best clinical indicator of fluid resuscitation: Urine output, best indicated by urine output of  >0.5 mL/kg/h in adults and >1 mL/kg/h in children.

Best indicator to determine the amount of fluid required in a patient with shock: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)

questions.text: A 63-year-old male who is a known Parkinson's patient is on tablet levodopa. He is to undergo an elective surgery. How many days prior to surgery should the drug be stopped?
questions.solution:
Levodopa can be continued on the day of surgery.

The following drugs can be continued on the day of surgery:

  • Antihypertensive medications: except ACE Inhibitors and ARBs
  • Cardiac medications (e.g., β-blockers, digoxin)
  • Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
  • Thyroid medications
