questions.text: A newborn male baby was diagnosed with undescended testis on the left side. The testis has not descended even after 3 months and an orchiopexy is planned. What is the most appropriate time for this surgery?

choices.text: When the age of the infant is less than 6 months
When the age of the infant is between 6 and 18 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate time for orchidopexy is between 6 to 18 months of age.

Orchidopexy is the surgery of choice for undescended testes. It is done in order to prevent the complications that might occur if the testes continue to remain inside the abdomen, such as infertility and the risk of malignancy. The surgery is usually performed between the ages of 6 months to 18 months. The testes and the spermatic cord are mobilized, the fibrous adhesions around the deep ring are divided, and the testes are repositioned in the scrotum, in a pouch constructed between the dartos muscle and the skin.

Cryptorchidism refers to the incomplete descent of the testes, but in their normal path from the abdomen to the scrotum. If they lie outside the normal path, they are referred to as ectopic testes. The occurrence of cryptorchidism is more common in premature infants. In two-thirds of the cases, the testes will reach the scrotum by 3 months of life; full descent after this time is unlikely. The descent of the testes may be arrested in any of the following positions:

  • Abdominal (15%)
  • Inguinal (25%)
  • High up in the scrotum (60%)
Undescended testes can give rise to a number of more serious consequences. This includes infertility, testicular malignancy, and testicular torsion. By the second year of life, there is a significant degeneration of the spermatogenic tissue. An orchidopexy done during adulthood (after puberty) will result in no significant fertility benefits and no reduction in the risk of testicular malignancy. Therefore, orchidopexy should be done as early as possible within the recommended age to prevent the occurrence of these complications. 
 
One important differential to be considered in these patients is retractile testis. Because of the strong cremasteric reflex, the stimulation of the scrotal skin causes the testis to ascend upwards and disappear into the inguinal canal. If it is a case of retractile testis, the scrotal skin will be well developed, in contrast to the underdeveloped scrotal skin seen in cryptorchidism. Further, the retractile testis that has ascended into the inguinal canal can be gently milked downwards, but this is not the case with true undescended testis.
 
In most cases of cryptorchidism, the testis can be palpated in the inguinal region and thus local exploration and orchidopexy can be done. In cases when the testis is not palpable, ultrasound and laparoscopy are done to pinpoint the location of the testis and plan further management. The diagnostic and treatment algorithm is given below.

questions.text: The hemodynamic function may improve during pregnancy in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The hemodynamic function may improve in aortic insufficiency during pregnancy.

Low peripheral resistance in pregnancy reduces regurgitation into the left ventricle and improves left ventricular function.

The hemodynamic function may also improve in

  • Mitral regurgitation: due to less regurgitation into the left atrium
  • Mitral valve prolapse: Increased preload may improve the alignment of the mitral valve leaflets and reduce regurgitation

Other options:

  • Hemodynamic function deteriorates in mitral stenosis due to increased preload and left atrial strain.
  • Fatal shunt reversal can occur in patent ductus arteriosus during pregnancy.
  • Shunt reversal in intracardiac shunts such as VSD can also worsen the hemodynamic status.

questions.text: Which of the following about toxoplasmosis is wrong?

choices.text: Pregnant women with negative serology are high-risk group
It takes 12 hours for the oocysts to become infective in the feces
The parasite can reproduce both sexually and asexually only in cats
Second trimester infections are less severe

questions.solution:
It takes 1 to 5 days for the oocysts to become infective after being excreted in the feces. Hence, daily removal of cat litter and safe disposal can prevent infection.

Other options:

  • Pregnant women with seronegative results are more prone for serious infection leading onto stillbirths, chorioretinitis, intracerebral calcifications, and hydrocephaly or microcephaly in the fetus.
  • Also, infection in the second or third trimester is less dangerous when compared to the first.
  • Only in cats it can reproduce in both sexual and asexual way. In other intermediate hosts such as rodents and humans, it can reproduce only asexually.

questions.text: Sargramostim is ____.
questions.solution:
Sargramostim is a recombinant human granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF), produced from yeast.

Indications for use:

  • Myeloid reconstitution after bone marrow transplant
  • Prophylaxis of neutropenia in myelosuppressive chemotherapy
  • Stem cell mobilization

Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor(GM CSF) is known to cause capillary leak syndrome. 

Filgrastim is recombinant human G-CSF produced in Escherichia coli. It is indicated by the treatment of severe neutropenia caused by myelosuppressive chemotherapy, chronic infections.

questions.text:
Which of the statements regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection are correct?
1. Hemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitides and, Streptococcus pneumoniae are the most common causative agents
2. Risk is greatest in patients who have undergone splenectomy for trauma
3. Risk is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy
4. Prophylactic vaccination should be done 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy
5. No vaccination is needed in case of an emergency splenectomy
questions.solution:
The risk of developing opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is greatest when splenectomy is done for haematological conditions than for post-trauma. 

Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is a major complication following splenectomy due to septicemia, which may result from an infection of:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Neisseria meningitides
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Escherichia coli.

The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy.

Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery.

In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: Neufeld reaction is used to identify which of the following?
questions.solution:
Neufeld reaction also called as Quellung reaction is used to identify capsulated organisms such as pneumococci, Neisseria meningitis, Haemophilus influenzae etc.

In this test, the colonies are mixed with antipolysaccharide serum on a slide, resulting in capsular swelling and agglutination.

questions.text: Non-union is a common complication in all of the following except _______.
questions.solution:
Non-union is NOT a common complication in trochanteric fractures.

Fractures that commonly progress to non-union include

  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Body of talus
  • Fracture scaphoid
  • Fracture lower third of tibia

questions.text: In the management of Alzheimer's disease, which of the following drug is an NMDA antagonist?
questions.solution:
Memantine is an NMDA antagonist useful in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

  • NMDA receptor permits the passage of Ca2+ and other cations present on hippocampal neurons.
  • Tacrine was the first approved anticholinesterase for Alzheimer’s disease. But, a high incidence of enhanced alanine aminotransferase and hepatotoxicity limited the use and was subsequently withdrawn.
  • Donepezil, galantamine, and rivastigmine are centrally acting cholinesterase inhibitors indicated for Alzheimer’s disease. 

Treatment of Alzheimer disease:

  • Drugs which increase cholinergic activity: Donepezil, Rivastigmine, Galantamine
  • NMDA antagonist: Memantine
  • Antioxidants can also be given

questions.text: According to DSM-V, Asperger’s disorder is diagnosed as_______________
questions.solution:
Under DSM-V,  Asperger’s disorder is diagnosed as autism spectrum disorder.

Autism spectrum disorder is a term introduced in DSM-V to replace the following diagnoses:

  • Autistic disorder
  • Asperger’s disorder
  • Rett’s disorder
  • Childhood disintegrative disorder
  • Pervasive developmental disorder (not otherwise specified)

The disorder is characterized by

1) Persistent social communication deficits across contexts

2) Restricted and repetitive pattern of interests, behaviour or activities.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about anti-mullerian hormone is false?
questions.solution:
Anti-mullerian hormone decreases with age. It is a peptide hormone produced by granulosa cells in females and Sertoli cells in males.

  • It is an indicator of ovarian reserve as it is secreted by ovarian follicles
  • It helps follicular development and maturation of oocytes
  • It is responsible for mullerian duct regression in males
  • It decreases with age due to the decline in the ovarian reserve

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ocular feature of myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Hypermetropia is not a feature of myasthenia gravis. The disorder is not associated with refractive errors.

Ptosis and convergence insufficiency are early and prominent features.

Nystagmoid jerks appear on lateral gaze in the abducting eye.

 Ocular myasthenia

  • If weakness remains restricted to the EOMs for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized, and these patients are said to have ocular MG.
  • Ocular involvement occurs in 90% of cases and is the presenting feature in 60%. Two-thirds of patients have both ptosis and diplopia.
  • Ptosis is insidious, bilateral and frequently asymmetrical. Typically worse at the end of the day and worse on prolonged (60 second) upgaze due to fatigue.
  • Cogan twitch sign is a brief upshoot of the eyelid as the eyes saccade from depression to the primary position. If one eyelid is elevated manually as the patient looks up, the fellow eyelid may show fine oscillatory movements.
  • Diplopia is frequently vertical, although any or all of the extraocular muscles may be affected. A pseudo-internuclear ophthalmoplegia may be seen. Patients with stable deviations may benefit from muscle surgery, botulinum toxin injection, or a combination of both.
  • Nystagmoid movements may be present on the extremes of gaze.

questions.text: Pseudo-athetosis is seen in lesions of the ______________
questions.solution:
Pseudo-athetosis is seen in nucleus cuneatus lesions. It is an athetoid movement of the extremities seen in loss of proprioception and is more pronounced when the eyes are closed. It can occur with lesions anywhere in the proprioceptive pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the condition shown in the radiograph below is false?

choices.text: Caesarean section may be considered in the next pregnancy
Usually treated with rest and pelvic binder

questions.solution:
The image shows pubic symphyseal diastasis and surgery is occasionally needed in separations greater than 4 cm.

The normal distance of the symphyseal joint is 0.4-0.5 cm and diastasis is diagnosed when it exceeds 1 cm. The condition is usually treated conservatively with rest in the lateral decubitus position and a pelvic binder. Since the risk of recurrence in subsequent pregnancies is high, caesarean section may be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as ‘Paradox gun’?
questions.solution:
Shotguns having a small portion of the bore near their muzzle end rifled are known as paradox guns.

Revolver, machine gun, automatic pistol are type of rifled weapons.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for Type 2 brittle asthma is
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice for Type 2 brittle asthma is subcutaneous epinephrine.

Brittle asthma can be classified as

  • Type I is characterized by wide swings in peak expiratory flow (PEF) despite maximal therapy.
  • Type II is characterized by normal or near normal lung function but very sudden attacks.

Treatment:

Type I brittle asthma

Oral corticosteroids or continuous subcutaneous infusion of terbutaline (or salbutamol)) and dietary exclusion of relevant foods to which the patient may be allergic may be helpful in selected patients.

Type II brittle asthma is difficult to manage because they do not respond well to corticosteroids and inhaled bronchodilators. It includes the use of self-administered subcutaneous adrenaline to abort the rapidly developing exacerbations.

questions.text: A patient with long-standing corticosteroid use was admitted for rhinocerebral mucormycosis. Which of the following is seen on microscopic examination?

choices.text: Broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching
Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule

questions.solution:
Under the microscope, mucormycosis is seen as broad hyphae with uneven thickness and irregular branching.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungus that can be found in patients with acidosis, such as diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies. The most common agent is Rhizopus oryzae. The common clinical form is rhinocerebral mucormycosis, in which the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, the eyes, and the brain invade, causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. Treatment is by surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration.

Other options:

Option B: Long conidiophores with terminal vesicles: Aspergillus

Option C: Spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick capsule: Cryptococcus neoformans

Option D: Oval, budding yeast cells: Candida

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: In apparent mineralocorticoid excess (AME) syndrome, the urine cortisol to cortisone ratio is  ______________
questions.solution:
The urine cortisol to cortisone ratio is increased in AME syndrome.

The syndrome is due to a mutation in the 11-β hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (11- β HSD) type 2 enzyme. Reduced activity of the enzyme causes an increase in cortisol at the renal tubules and increased stimulation of the mineralocorticoid receptors, mimicking a mineralocorticoid excess.

Hypertension, hypokalemia, reduced renin, and aldosterone levels are the other findings seen in AME syndrome.

11- β HSD type 2 enzyme inactivates cortisol to cortisone in the renal tubules. 

11- β HSD type 1 enzyme converts cortisone to cortisol and is present in the liver, adipose tissue, and the brain.

questions.text: Reverse batwing appearance in chest x-ray is seen in:
questions.solution:
Reverse batwing appearance in chest x-ray image is seen in chronic pulmonary eosinophilia

Reverse bat wing pulmonary opacities refer to peripheral opacities of the lungs, sparing the perihilar region.

The differential diagnosis for reverse batwing appearance in chest x-ray image:

  • Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia
  • Organizing pneumonia (formerly bronchiolitis obliterans with organizing pneumonia (BOOP))
  • Bronchoalveolar carcinoma
  • Pulmonary contusion: in the setting of trauma
  • Pulmonary vasculitis
  • Aspiration

questions.text: A patient has a dry eye and reduced nasal secretions. The location of a lesion might be in the ____.
questions.solution:
Parasympathetic (secretomotor) supply to the lacrimal gland, glands of the nasal mucosa and palate travel in the nerve of pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve) and reach the sphenopalatine ganglion where they relay before reaching the target.

They also supply the blood vessels of nose and cause vasodilation.

Sympathetic nerve fibres come from upper two thoracic segments of spinal cord, pass through superior cervical ganglion, travel in deep petrosal nerve and join the parasympathetic fibres of greater petrosal nerve to form the nerve of pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve). They reach the nasal cavity without relay in the sphenopalatine ganglion. Their stimulation causes vasoconstriction.

 

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text: Nischay kit provided by the government to ASHA under NRHM is used for?
questions.solution:
Nischay kit provided by the government to ASHA under NRHM is used for early pregnancy testing.

Nishchay is a home-based Pregnancy Test Kit (PTK) that was launched under NRHM across the country and was later anchored with the Family Planning Division. The pregnancy test kits are being made available at the sub-center level and are also distributed to ASHA.

These pregnancy test kits are supplied free of cost and are home-based and easy to use. It facilitates early detection and also decision-making for the outcomes of pregnancy. Helping to detect pregnancy as early as one week after the missed period, provides an early opportunity for medical termination of pregnancy, thus saving lives lost to unsafe abortions.

Note: NIKSHAY is an online tool launched by the government for RNTCP to monitor tuberculosis in the country.

questions.text: Pseudo chancre redux is a feature that you would expect to see in a patient with:
questions.solution:
Pseudo-chancre redux is a gummatous lesion seen in tertiary syphilis.

This condition occurs at the site of the previously healed chancre.  Adjacent lymph nodes are not enlarged.  It is not infectious and treponemes can hardly be demonstrated from the lesion.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema palladium. It is usually acquired through sexual contact and co-exists with other sexually transmitted diseases. However, congenital syphillis is acquired as a transplacental infection. The stages of untreated syphilis in the order of their occurrence are:
 
  • Primary syphilis presents as a papule on external genitalia that rapidly ulcerates to form a primary chancre. Inguinal lymphadenopathy usually accompanies the primary syphilitic lesion.
  • Secondary syphilis is the stage when generalized manifestations of syphilis appear on the skin and mucous membranes. A macular rash is commonly seen and this stage may be preceded by constitutional symptoms such as fever, sore throat, and malaise.
  • Latent syphilis is the stage when there are no clinical features of the active disease but serological testing for the disease is positive.  
  • Late syphilis (Tertiary syphilis) commonly presents as superficial or nodular punched out ulcers or gummas(granulomas appearing as cutaneous plaques or nodules with central ulceration) appears 6 months after exposure. It may also present as neurosyphilis and cardiovascular syphilis. 
Serological testing is done using standard non-treponemal antibody tests like VDRL and RPR. Specific treponemal antibody tests like TPHA, and FTA-ABS are further required. 
Microscopically, Trepenoma palladium is identified with a characteristic wave-like appearance on darkfield microscopy.
 
Parenteral penicillin G is the drug of choice for all stages of syphilis. If the patient has a history of drug allergies, it is advisable to keep the patient under observation for 15 to 20 mins after injection. An emergency kit for the management of anaphylaxis should always be available.
Treatment of recent sexual contacts is recommended. 

Note:

  • Chancre redux is a highly infectious recurrence of the primary sore at its original site of previously healed chancre within first 2 years of the disease i.e early Relapsing Syphilis. This may be associated with painless lymphadenopathy.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: Constitutional growth delay is characterized by all of the following except ____.

choices.text: Length and weight are normal at birth
The pubertal growth spurt is delayed
Is usually treated with recombinant growth factor

questions.solution:
Constitutional short stature does not require any therapy.

In constitutional growth delay, length and weight measurement of affected children are normal at birth. Growth is normal for the first 4-12 months of life. Height is sustained at a lower percentile during childhood.

The pubertal growth spurt is delayed, so their growth rates continue to decline after their classmates have begun to accelerate.

questions.text: Peppering results from _______.

choices.text: Grains of gunpowder being driven into the skin
The flame emerging from the muzzle
Superficial deposit of smoke on the skin
Deposition of lead or other metal in the skin

questions.solution:
Grains of unburnt gunpowder driven into the skin producing tattooing is known as peppering or stippling.

Other options:

The flame emerging from the muzzle: Scorching.

Superficial deposit of smoke on the skin: Smudging.

Deposition of lead or other metal in the skin: Lead ring/Metal ring around entry wound.

questions.text: A teenage boy presented features suggestive of hereditary pancreatitis. Which of the following is true about his condition?

choices.text: Most common presentation is chronic pancreatitis

questions.solution:
Hereditary pancreatitis is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with mutations in the cationic trypsinogen gene located on chromosome 7. It has 80% penetrance.

The most common presentation of autosomal dominant hereditary pancreatitis is recurrent acute pancreatitis. Patients of hereditary pancreatitis usually develop acute pancreatitis in their teens and chronic pancreatitis within the next two decades. These patients have a higher risk of progressing into pnacreatic cancer by the age of 70. 

The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are - gallstones, alcoholism, post-ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography), drugs (steroids, thiazides, azathioprine, etc.), hypercalcemia, etc. 

The classical presentation includes acute severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and relieved by leaning forward. Nausea and vomiting can also be present. Clinical signs such as hypotension, tachycardia, Grey Turner sign (bluish discolouration of the flanks) and Cullen’s sign (bluish discolouration around the umbilicus) can be present.

Laboratory findings include elevated serum amylase and serum lipase. Serum amylase levels are non-specific, while serum lipase is more specific, and lipase is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours from the onset of symptoms.

Management involves keeping the patient nil per oral, fluid replacement, and pain control. Antibiotics are rarely required unless the infection spreads.

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman brought to the psychiatric OPD by her friend who says that a popular actor is in love with her and stalks her. The woman’s friend refutes her claims. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erotomania is a delusional disorder where the patient believes someone is in love with him/her, against evidence to the contrary. It is also known as De Clérambault syndrome.

The lover in the delusion is often a person of higher social status. It is more common in women.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: The cervical mucous of a young female patient undergoing infertility evaluation exhibits the characteristic spinnbarkeit phenomenon. Which of the following properties is the cervical mucus associated with?
questions.solution:
At the time of ovulation, due to the estrogen effect, the cervical mucous is thin and profuse with great elasticity and can withstand stretching up to 10 cm. This phenomenon is called spinnbarkeit or the thread test for estrogen activity.

When viewed under the low-power microscope, it shows the characteristic ferning pattern due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucous secreted under estrogen effect.

During the secretory phase, due to the progesterone effect, the cervical mucous becomes tenacious and its viscosity increases so that it loses the property of spinnbarkeit and fractures when put under tension. This property is called tack.

questions.text: Pepsinogen is activated by _________
questions.solution:
Pepsinogen is activated to pepsin by hydrochloric acid.

When pepsinogen is secreted, it has no digestive activity. When it comes in contact with hydrochloric acid, it is activated to form active pepsin. Pepsin is an active proteolytic enzyme at an optimum pH of 1.8-3.5 and is inactivated when it mixes with alkaline intestinal secretions.

It is an active proteolytic enzyme in a highly acidic medium optimum pH 1.8 to 3.5, but above a pH of about 5, it has almost no proteolytic activity and becomes completely inactivated in a short time.

Related Pearl: Classification of proteases

questions.text: The rhythmic fluctuations in the functioning of living beings follows a circadian rhythm that is synchronized to the day-night cycle in the environment. This synchronisation depends on the _______
questions.solution:
The rhythmic fluctuations in the functioning of living beings follows a circadian rhythm that is synchronized to the day-night cycle in the environment. This synchronisation depends on the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN).

SCN receive information about the light–dark cycle via a special neural pathway, the retinohypothalamic fibers.

Efferents from the SCN initiate neural and humoral signals that entrain a wide variety of well-known circadian rhythms including the sleep–wake cycle and the secretion of the pineal hormone melatonin. 

In the absence of such synchronization, the circadian rhythm becomes progressively more out of phase with light-dark cycle because they are longer or shorter than 24 hours.

questions.text: A mother has brought her 6-week-old child for vaccination, and she wants to know if there are any new vaccines that her child should take according to Mission Indradhanush. Which of the following vaccines was introduced recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus vaccine was recently introduced in Intensified Mission Indradhanush.

Rotavirus vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine administered orally. The different Rotavirus vaccines available are Rotarix, RotaTeq, Rotavac, and Rotasiil. It can be given as a 3-dose schedule starting at 6 weeks of age with a minimum interval of 4 weeks between the doses.

Usually, catch-up immunization is not recommended due to the difficulty in ascertaining the age of the children, and giving the first dose of vaccine beyond 12 weeks of age is associated with an increased risk of intussusception. 

Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to achieve the same goal by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month.

The diseases are as follows:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hepatitis B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

Diseases included recently:

  • Rotavirus (vaccine given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age)
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • Haemophilus influenzae type B disease (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese encephalitis

questions.text: In progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, which of the following is not involved?
questions.solution:
Spinal cord and optic nerve are spared in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus; because the virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes, demyelination is its principal pathologic effect.

It is also  a life-threatening serious side effect of natalizumab.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is embedded in the mitochondrial membrane?
questions.solution: Succinate dehydrogenase is the only TCA cycle enzyme to be embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It is also the only enzyme to participate in both the TCA cycle and the electron transport chain. It couples the oxidation of succinate to fumarase in the TCA cycle with the reduction of ubiquinone to ubiquinol in the electron transport chain.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl complains of lower abdominal pain. History reveals she has mild pain around the time of ovulation every month and the pain subsides within a few hours. Pelvic examination is normal. How will you manage the condition?
questions.solution:
Acute lower abdominal pain around ovulation that typically subsides within a few hours indicates ovulatory pain or Mittelschmerz syndrome. It is treated conservatively with rest and NSAIDs such as acetaminophen.

The pain has been hypothesised to be due to the following reasons:

  • Swelling of the ovarian follicles around the time of ovulation
  • Disruption of the ovarian surface epithelium during ovulation
  • Irritation of the peritoneum by blood from ruptured Graafian follicle
  • Contraction of ovarian smooth muscle and ligaments
  • Contraction of the fallopian tube

The pain may be one sided or bilateral. When one sided, it can be used to predict the ovary involved in ovulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding the subtypes of Guillain Barre syndrome?

choices.text: Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) - more common in adults than children
Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)-First attack at nodes of Ranvier
Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN)-Recovery is rapid and complete
Miller Fisher syndrome-Characterized by opthalmoplegia,ataxia and areflexia

questions.solution:
Recovery in acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN) is slow and incomplete.

questions.text: During the rainy season, a patient was diagnosed with dengue fever. In this patient, lowering of the hypothalamic temperature set point causes ____________
questions.solution:
Lowering of the hypothalamic set point in fever causes profuse sweating and cutaneous vasodilation. It is due to the removal of pyrogens towards the resolution of the fever and is also known as fever flush or crisis. The body temperature is lowered through cutaneous heat loss.

Cutaneous vasoconstriction, chills, and shivering are seen during the onset of fever when the hypothalamic set point is raised by pyrogens. The body temperature is raised through these methods of conservation and generation of heat. Chills only occur until the new hypothalamic set point is reached. Following this, as long as the pyrogens are present, the body temperature is regulated similar to the normal mechanism but at a higher hypothalamic set point.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are caused by misfolding of proteins, except _____.
questions.solution:
Her's disease is due to deficiency of liver glycogen phosphorylase.

Other three given conditions are caused by the misfolding of proteins:

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is caused by abnormal folding of rhodopsin, resulting in photoreceptor loss and cell death, resulting in blindness.
  • Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease is caused by prions due to abnormal folding of PrPsc causes neuronal cell death.
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia due to a defect in the LDL receptor.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions causes least fall in haptoglobin level?
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, only thalassemia causes extravascular hemolysis and hence the fall in haptoglobin level is minimal in it.

Large amount of hemoglobin released during intravascular hemolysis binds with haptoglobin and forms a complex, which are removed by phagocytes.

questions.text: A group of researchers decided to conduct a study evaluating the relationship between thalidomide and fetal anomalies. The study design will be a case-control study. All of the following are advantages of case-control studies except:
questions.solution:
Relative risk can be calculated only in a cohort study and not in a case-control study.

A case-control study or a retrospective study involves two populations- cases and controls. It progresses from effect to cause.
 
Advantages of a case-control study:
  • Relatively quick and cost-effective
  • Easy to carry out
  • Suitable to investigate rare diseases
  • Less risk to subjects
  • Minimal ethical problems
  • Relatively fewer subjects are required

Relative risk refers to the ratio of the incidence of the disease among the exposed to the incidence of the disease among the non-exposed. It directly measures the strength of the association between the cause and the effect. Cohort studies provide a direct estimate of the relative risk since incidence can be calculated. 

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A primigravida comes to the primary health center for a routine antenatal visit and enquires about consumption of iron tablets. Which of the following is recommended for pregnant women during the antenatal period based on Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme?

choices.text: 100 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 180 days
100 mg of elemental iron for 180 days

questions.solution:
According to Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid are given daily for a minimum of 180 days during pregnancy. It is to be started from the fourth month of pregnancy and to be continued for 180 days, post-partum.

Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme (2018) is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It follows a 6x6x6 strategy. Here, 6 groups of beneficiaries are assisted by 6 interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.

The six distinct groups of beneficiaries are children of 6-59 months of age, children of 5-9 years, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. 

The six interventions are:

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation prophylactically
  • Deworming
  • Behavior change communication campaign
  • Using digital methods and point of care treatment
  • Provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: Which is the most important intervention in preventing necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in a preterm baby?
questions.solution:
Human milk is the most important intervention in preventing necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in a preterm baby.

Immaturity of the intestinal epithelial barrier and neonatal mucosal immune system predispose the premature infant to bacterial invasion, which triggers the sequence of NEC.

Human milk provides oligosaccharides, acetylhydrolase, and mucosal immune components, alters bacterial flora, affects the mucus coat, decreases epithelial permeability, increases peristalsis, and lowers gastric ph, which enhances barrier function.

questions.text: Lorenzo oil is used in the treatment of
questions.solution:
Lorenzo oil is used in the treatment of adrenoleukodystrophy.

Lorenzo oil is 4:1 mixture of glycerol trioleate and glyceryl trierucate.

Only available to patients participating in clinical trials.

Upto 3 mL/day in children 8 years of age has been used in clinical study.

Thrombocytopenia is a reported side effect.

Hot fermentation method is also known as Bangalore method.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in Wilson’s disease?
questions.solution:
In Wilson's disease, there is inadequate excretion of copper in bile and impaired incorporation of copper into apo-ceruloplasmin. The inadequate biliary excretion is due to mutations in the ATP7B gene which encodes a copper transporting P-type ATPase.

There is no defect in production of apo-ceruloplasmin and the disease is not caused by defective intestinal absorption or renal excretion.

questions.text: Manual exploration of the uterus for tears is done routinely in all except _______________
questions.solution:
Uterotonics are administered in uterine atony with fluid resuscitation and bimanual compression of the uterus.

Refractory bleeding is treated with balloon tamponade or surgical procedures such as compression sutures, pelvic vessel ligation/embolization and hysterectomy.

Breech extraction, internal podalic version and vaginal delivery after caesarean section are all associated with the risk of tears/uterine rupture and manual uterine exploration is done routinely.

questions.text: The gastrocolic reflex is mediated by
questions.solution:
The gastrocolic reflex is mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia.

Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activate afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. This is the reason for frequent defecation after meals in children. This reflex can also be amplified by the action of gastrin.

Other reflexes that involve the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia include the following:

  • Enterogastric reflex: Signals from colon and small intestinal signals stop gastric motility and secretion.
  • Colonoileal reflex: Signals from the colon prevent ileal emptying

The brain stem and spinal cord are involved in:

  • Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract
  • Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity
  • Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall.

Local reflexes mediated by the enteric nervous system regulate local secretion, peristalsis, mixing contractions, and ileus.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with ophthalmic toxicity?
questions.solution:
The most serious adverse effect of ethambutol is optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green.

Clinical correlate:

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination prior to the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following serotype is an uncommon cause of meningitis?
questions.solution: Meningitis due to N. meningitidis is most commonly caused by strains A, B, C, X, W135, and Y.

questions.text: The most common aneuploidy associated with azoospermia is _________________
questions.solution:
The most common aneuploidy associated with azoospermia is 47XXY karyotype, also known as Klinefelter syndrome.

Mosaic Klinefelter syndrome (46XY/47XXY karyotype) has a weaker association with azoospermia than Klinefelter syndrome.

Azoospermia is less common in mixed gonadal dysgenesis (45X/46XY mosaicism) and 47XYY karyotype.

questions.text: The most common cause of amputation in India is ?
questions.solution:
Injury is the commonest cause of amputation in the developing countries.

The injury may be due to road traffic accidents or as a part of occupational accidents.

Peripheral vascular diseases are the most common cause of amputations in the elderly.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to the emergency with watery diarrhea. The diagnosis was made on stool cytotoxin assay. On colonoscopy, ulcers, plaque's and pseudo-membranes were visualized. Patient condition improved drastically after the use of metronidazole. CECT finding is given below. What is the name of the sign seen on CECT?
questions.solution:
The CT image depicts accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

The accordion sign is seen on CT examinations of the abdomen and refers to the similarity between the thickened edematous wall of pseudomembranous colitis to that of an accordion. The appearance arises as a result of oral contrast being trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudo-membranes formed on the luminal surface of the colon.

Pseudomembranous colitis is a severe form of Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI), typically caused by prolonged use of antibiotics such as cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin, which disrupt the gut flora, causing a spectrum of disease ranging from watery diarrhoea to fulminant, life-threatening colitis. The bacteria release toxins that damage the colon, causing diarrhoea, abdominal pain, fever, and the formation of whitish-yellow plaques (pseudomembranes). Diagnosis is made through stool tests for toxins or bacteria. Risk factors include advanced age, poor hygiene, and gastrointestinal surgery.

questions.text: What is done after delivery of the fetus in the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows placenta percreta, where hysterectomy is the best course after delivery of the fetus. It is also the preferred course in placenta increta.

Any attempt at removal of the placenta causes profuse bleeding and a placenta left in-situ is associated with a high rate of complications and subsequent need for hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about displacement reactions is false?

choices.text: A group is transferred from one substrate to another
Each reaction has two Km values
Enzymes are transiently modified in single displacement reactions

questions.solution:
Enzymes are transiently modified in double displacement reactions.

Displacement reactions involve the transfer of a group between two substrates. The reactions can take place in a single step or in two steps.

A single step reaction involves the direct transfer of a group between two substrates bound to an enzyme. Such reactions are called sequential or single displacement reactions. In a two step reaction, the group is first transferred to the enzyme and then to the second substrate. These reactions are called double displacement reactions.

Each substrate has its own Km value and most of the displacement reactions follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics.

questions.text: M protein and pili are virulence factors respectively for which of the following pairs?
questions.solution:
M protein and pili are virulence factor for Streptococcus pyogenes and N gonorrhoeae, respectively.

M protein: 

M protein is a filamentous structure anchored to the cell membrane of the streptococcus.  

It provides virulence to Streptococcus by inhibiting activation of the alternate complement pathway thereby inhibiting phagocytosis.


Pilli: 

Also, known as fimbriae seen in N gonorrhoeae enhance attachment to host cells and resistance to phagocytosis. Another virulent factor for gonorrhoea is por, which impact intracellular killing of gonococci within neutrophils by preventing phagolysosome fusion.

questions.text: Alpha blocker which may cause apoptosis of prostate is?
questions.solution:
Doxazosin,prazosin, and terazosin have shown apoptosis effect on prostatic smooth muscle cells. This could be related to their quinazoline moiety.

Tamsulosin is a non-quinazoline benzenesulfonamide having least apoptosis effect on prostatic cells.

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha receptor antagonist.

Classification of alpha 1 selective antagonist:

Selective antagonist action on alpha 1A over alpha 1B receptors:

  • Silodosin
  • Tamsulosin

Non-subtype selective alpha 1 receptor antagonists:

  • Prazosin
  • Terazosin
  • Doxazosin
  • Alfuzosin

Note: Silodosin has a selective antagonist action on alpha 1A receptors over alpha 1B receptors that can help in minimizing the postural hypotension and dizziness associated with prazosin.

questions.text: Fasanella-Servat operation is done in ___________.
questions.solution:

Other options:

It is not done in myasthenia gravis as the levator function is variable.

In Bell’s palsy, tarsorraphy is performed to prevent exposure keratitis.

Depending on the levator function, a frontalis suspension or levator resection procedure is done in severe congenital ptosis.

questions.text: Hypothermia is used as a treatment modality in all except ___.
questions.solution:
Cardiac arrhythmias are initiated by hypothermia and hence hypothermia is not used for its treatment.

Hypothermia reduces metabolic oxygen requirements and can be protective during cerebral or cardiac ischemia.

Induced hypothermia is used as a treatment modality in following conditions:

  • Cerebral ischemia
  • Hyperthermia
  • Cardiac surgery
  • Post-cardiac arrest

questions.text: The false statement regarding the method shown in the image below is _____.

choices.text: It is a part of warm chain
It can be done by fathers also
Can be carried out by hemodynamically unstable mothers

questions.solution:
The image shows kangaroo mother care. It can be carried out by hemodynamically stable mothers who are on IV fluids, CPAP, or even ventilators.

Kangaroo mother care is part of warm chain transportation of babies, especially when incubator ambulances are not available for transportation of the baby.

Kangaroo discharge: early discharge from hospital has been shown to cause reduced rates of hospital-acquired infections.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A person showing two cell lines derived from two different zygotes is known as:
questions.solution:
The phenomenon by which a person showing two cell lines derived from two different zygotes is known as chimerism.

A chimera is essentially a single organism that's made up of cells from two or more "individual” that is, it contains two sets of DNAs, with the code to make two separate organisms.

Example: In Dizygotic Twinning, the morula is a chimera consisting of an assortment of cells with two different genotypes.

The molecular mechanisms that establish twin embryogenesis are active in the chimeric morula and are responsible for the latter “splitting” of the inner cell mass. The twinning chimeric morula can travel two different routes, leading to either monochorionic or dichorionic twins.

Other options:

Chromosomal mosaicism is defined as the presence of two or more different chromosome complements within an individual developed from a single zygote.

questions.text: Goodpasture syndrome is due to _________.

choices.text: Autoantibodies against noncollagenous domain of Collagen IV
Autoantibodies against noncollagenous domain of Collagen II
Autoantibodies against collagenous domain of Collagen II
Autoantibodies against collagenous domain of Collagen IV

questions.solution:
Goodpasture syndrome is due to autoantibodies against noncollagenous(NC1) domain of α3 chain of collagen IV.

The antibodies cause inﬂammatory destruction of the basement membrane in renal glomeruli and pulmonary alveoli, giving rise to glomerulonephritis and hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis.

questions.text: The secondary action of the inferior oblique muscle is tested by asking the patient to look _____________
questions.solution:
The secondary action of the inferior oblique muscle is elevation, which is tested by asking the patient to look up and in. In the adducted position of the eyeball, elevation is predominantly due to the inferior oblique, so it is ideally tested in this position.

 

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: Identify the ECG.
questions.solution:
The above ECG is suggestive of dextrocardia based on the following features.

  • Lead I is inverted with a negative P wave, QRS complex & T wave.
  • P wave is inverted in aVR and aVL
  • Reversal of the usual pattern of Lead aVR.
  • There is a loss of normal R-wave progression from V1 - V6 with dominant S waves throughout.
  • Right-axis deviation

Differential diagnosis:

Accidental reversal of right and left arm electrodes may produce similar findings as dextrocardia in the limb leads, but with normal appearances in the precordial leads.

 

Reference - The ECG, by John Hampton, Page no. 57.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common hypercoagulable state?
questions.solution:
Factor V mutation is the most common cause of hypercoagulable state.

The mutation alters an amino acid residue in factor V and makes it resistant to proteolysis by protein C.

The hypercoagulable states less frequently cause arterial or intracardiac thrombosis but are important risk factors for venous thrombosis.

Heterozygotes carry a fivefold increased risk for venous thrombosis, while homozygotes having a 50-fold increased risk.

Absence of CD20 in Follicular lymphoma
Absence of CD5 in Follicular lymphoma

CD5 is present only in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and not follicular lymphoma.

CD19 and CD20 are present in both CLL and follicular lymphoma.

questions.text: Which hemorrhage is more common in term babies as compared to preterm?
questions.solution:
Subdural hemorrhages are more common in term babies as compared to preterm.

Massive subdural hemorrhage, often associated with tears in the tentorium cerebelli or less frequently in falx cerebri, is rare but is encountered more often in full term than in premature infants.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for carotid endarterectomy in patients with carotid stenosis except:
questions.solution:
Persistent hypertension is not an indication for carotid endarterectomy in patients with carotid stenosis.

The current guidelines for carotid endarterectomy in symptomatic patients is as follows:

70% or greater carotid stenosis and

  • Ipsilateral amaurosis fugax or monocular blindness
  • Contralateral facial paralysis or paresthesia
  • Arm/leg paralysis or paresthesia
  • Hemianopia
  • Dysphasia (if dominant hemisphere)
  • Sensory or visual inattention/neglect

questions.text: The following images are characteristic of _____.
questions.solution:
Melkersson–Rosenthal Syndrome is a triad of

  • Recurrent facial paralysis
  • Recurrent orofacial edema
  • Fissured tongue (lingua plicata)

The major diagnostic criterion is persistent or recurrent non-pitting facial edema that cannot be explained by infection, malignancy, or connective tissue disorder. The edematous lips assume a chapped, fissured, red-brown appearance.

Facial paralysis is the least common symptom of the triad, and it has an abrupt onset that is identical to that in Bell's palsy.

questions.text: Migratory necrolytic skin rash is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Glucagonoma, a neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas presents with migratory necrolytic skin rash.

Glucagonoma is a rare syndrome, with a classic presentation of the “4 D’s”: diabetes, dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis(positive Homan’s sign and Moses Sign is suggestive of DVT), and depression.

Necrolytic migrating erythema/skin rash is a characteristic skin lesion seen in glucagonoma patients usually before the appearance of other symptoms It is thought to be caused by low levels of amino acids. Therefore parenteral administration of amino acids was found to result in the disappearance of the skin lesions.

Diagnosis of this condition is made by measuring fasting glucagon levels. A level of > 1000pg/ml is diagnostic. (Normal - 100pg/ml) Management involves the correction of nutritional deficiencies with enteral nutrition. Octreotide can help reverse the catabolic state. DVT prophylaxis should be provided as soon as possible. Surgery can be done if the mass is resectable.

questions.text: A 50-year-old asymptomatic woman who underwent screening for diabetes had a positive urine Benedict’s test and a negative glucose oxidase reaction. An osazone test shows needle-shaped crystals under the microscope. How would you treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The woman has essential fructosuria, which is asymptomatic and needs no treatment. In this condition, there is a deficiency of hepatic fructokinase and fructose is excreted in the urine. Benedict’s test for reducing sugars is positive, whereas the glucose oxidase test specific for glucose is negative. Osazone reaction with phenylhydrazine produces needle-shaped crystals.

Other reducing sugars also form osazones.

Galactose Rhombic plate-shaped crystals
Lactose Cotton ball/ Powder-puff/ Hedgehog crystals

questions.text: Immunoblotting is a technique used in immunology also called as _______
questions.solution:

  • Northwestern blotting is used to identify the interaction between the RNA and proteins.
  • Nephelometry is used to quantify a wide variety of analytes in serum or plasma such as immunoglobulins.

questions.text: The structure that does not cross the midline is _____.
questions.solution:
The left gonadal vein terminates in the left renal vein and does not cross the midline.

Other options:

Left renal vein crosses to the right in the angle between the abdominal aorta posteriorly and the superior mesenteric artery anteriorly, to empty into the inferior vena cava.

Left brachiocephalic vein arises posterior to the sternal end of the left clavicle, anterior to the cervical pleura, and descends obliquely to the right (crosses), posterior to the superior half of the manubrium sterni, reaching the sternal end of the first right costal cartilage where it joins the right brachiocephalic vein to form the superior vena cava.

Hemiazygos vein crosses posterior to the aorta and oesophagus, and either anterior or posterior to the thoracic duct, and usually terminates in the azygos vein at the level of the eighth thoracic vertebra.

questions.text: Malabsorption in Whipple’s disease is due to which of the following reasons?

choices.text: Damage due to villi by the bacteria
Lymphatic obstruction by the organism-laden macrophages
Pancreatic insufficiency due to damage to the pancreas

questions.solution:
Malabsorption in Whipple’s disease is due to lymphatic obstruction by organism-laden macrophages within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes.

The clinical presentation is commonly a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia.

The following image shows foamy macrophages in lamina propria, which is characteristically seen in Whipple’s disease.

questions.text: The following radiograph can be seen in ________.
questions.solution:

It is seen when there is bilateral spondylolisthesis of L5 over S1.

questions.text: Ratio of chest compressions to breathing during cardiopulmonary resuscitation in a new-born who sustained cardiac arrest after delivery is:
questions.solution:
The compression ventilation ratio for new-born is 3:1.

According to 2015 AHA guidelines, chest compressions are initiated if the new-born's heart rate remains <60 bpm despite adequate ventilation for 30 seconds.

During neonatal resuscitation, the chest compression rate is 90 per minute accompanied by 30 ventilations per minute with one ventilation interposed after every third compression (3:1 ratio). Whenever chest compressions are provided, the oxygen concentration is increased to 100 percent.

Thus, the ventilation rate is reduced from the 40 to 60 breaths per minute in the absence of chest compression to 30 breaths in the presence of chest compression.

questions.text: Accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes is treated with recombinant ____________
questions.solution:
Accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes is seen in Pompe disease (type 2 GSD) and is treated with recombinant alpha glucosidase/acid maltase.

This is the only glycogen storage disorder with lysosomal accumulation of glycogen. A small amount of glycogen is degraded by the lysosomal enzyme, α (1→4)-glucosidase also known as acid maltase. A deficiency of this enzyme causes the accumulation of glycogen in vacuoles in the lysosomes. This is called type II GSD or Pompe’s disease.

Another GSD that is also a lysosomal storage disorder is Danon disease (or glycogen storage disease Type IIb)

Glycogen storage disorders that are associated with the following findings:

  • Liver cirrhosis: Types III, IV, IX GSD
  • Renal dysfunction: Type I GSD
  • Neurologic involvement: Type II GSD

In glucose-6-phosphatase and glycogen phosphorylase deficiency, glycogen accumulates in the cytosol.

Beta glucosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher’s disease, which is a sphingolipidosis.

questions.text: What is the correct order of the normal phases of wound healing?

choices.text: Remodeling phase > Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase
Hemostatic phase > Inflammatory phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase
Inflammatory phase > Hemostatic phase > Remodeling phase > Proliferative phase
Inflammatory phase > Hemostatic phase > Proliferative phase > Remodeling phase

questions.solution:
The correct order of the normal phases of wound healing is the hemostatic phase > inflammatory phase > proliferative phase > remodeling phase.

The inflammatory phase begins immediately after wounding and lasts 2-3 days. Bleeding is followed by vasoconstriction and thrombus formation to limit blood loss. Occasionally, the early part of the inflammatory phase is called the hemostatic phase.

The proliferative phase lasts from the 3rd day to the 3rd week consisting mainly of fibroblast activity with the production of collagen and ground substance, growth of new blood vessels, and re-epithelialization of the wound surface.

The remodeling phase is characterized by maturation of collagen- type 1 replacing type 3 until a ratio of 4:1 is achieved. The mature collagen leads to increased tensile strength and represents approximately 80% of the uninjured skin strength.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with right iliac fossa pain and a USG pelvis revealed bilateral heterogenous adnexal masses. On CT abdomen, the gastric wall is diffusely thickened. Identify the false statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Unilateral masses preferentially involve right ovary

questions.solution:
The patient has Krukenberg tumour of the ovaries secondary to linitis plastica and ovarian surface adhesions are uncommon in this condition. Krukenberg tumours are ovarian metastases of mucin secreting adenocarcinoma cells. The metastases are seen as heterogenous adnexal masses on a pelvic USG and the primary is most commonly found in the stomach.

Active ovulation is associated with Krukenberg tumour as it disrupts the ovarian surface epithelium and creates raw areas where the malignant cells could implant. The implanted tumour cells proliferate, form crypts and become inclusion cysts in the stroma of the ovary. Since they are present in the ovarian stroma, the capsular surface is smooth and is free of adhesions.

It is more often bilateral, but when unilateral, the right ovary is preferentially involved. This is because the right ovary is more frequently involved in ovulation than the left. The prognosis is bad and debulking surgery along with chemotherapy can be done.

questions.text: Melatonin is synthesized from ___________
questions.solution: Melatonin is synthesized from 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin) in the pineal gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogen causing Lassa fever?

choices.text: It consists of one single-stranded RNA molecule
Mastomys natalensis is the principle rodent reservoir
The infection is acquired through a tick bite
Ribavirin is least effective during the early stages

questions.solution:
House rat (Mastomys natalensis) is the principle reservoir of Lassa virus.

Other options:

  • It is made up of two single-stranded RNA molecules.
  • The infection is acquired through the inhalation of the infected material.
  • Ribavirin is most effective during the early stages of infection.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding salivary gland neoplasms are correct?

1. 80-90% of parotid gland tumors are malignant 2. 90% of sublingual tumors are malignant 3. 60-70% of submandibular gland tumors are benign 4. Parotid gland is the most common site for salivary gland tumors
questions.solution:
Parotid gland is the most common site for salivary gland tumors and most of them are benign (80-90%). In contrast, 90% of the sublingual gland tumors are malignant but rare in occurrence.

Submandibular gland tumors are predominantly benign (60-70%).

questions.text: M pneumoniae initiate infection by ______.

choices.text: Elaboration of a polysaccharide capsule that inhibits phagocytosis
Endocytosis by ciliated respiratory epithelial cells

questions.solution: M pneumoniae initiate infection by adhering to respiratory epithelium cells mediated by P1 adhesin.

questions.text: All of the following anticancer drugs acts on the M phase of the cell cycle except ______.
questions.solution:
Bleomycin acts on G2 phase of the cell cycle.

All the other drugs given above act on M phase of the cell cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following patterns seen in an A scan is characteristic of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
A characteristic V-Y pattern is seen in A scans of retinoblastoma. The spikes are due to echodense areas of tumor tissue and calcification, while the troughs are due to necrotic areas.

This pattern is not seen in conditions that mimic retinoblastoma (pseudogliomas) such as toxocariasis, persistent hyperplastic vitreous, Norrie disease, retrolental fibroplasia, and inflammatory vitreal deposits.

questions.text: The IUCD LNG-20 is effective for how many years?
questions.solution:
The IUCD LNG-20 (Mirena) is effective for 5 years.

A 52 mg LNG IUD with an initial release rate of approximately 20 mcg/day, which declines to an average release of 10 mcg/day at five years. US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved for five years of use.

It has a low pregnancy rate of 0.2 per 100 women.

The textbook of Park 26th edition page no 577 supports the effective period of 10 years for IUD LNG-20. While WHO and FDA approve it for 5 years.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables

    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week
