questions.text: All of the following are true about myasthenia gravis except _____.

choices.text: Drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis is Edrophonium.
Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in myasthenia gravis.

questions.solution:
In myasthenia gravis, remissions are rarely complete or permanent; unrelated infections or systemic disorders can lead to myasthenic weakness and may precipitate crisis.

Peak incidence of MG occurs in women in their twenties and thirties and men in their fifties and sixties. Overall female to male ratio is 3:2.

Intravenous injection of edrophonium shows remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles in patients with myasthenic weakness. This test is used for initial diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

In contrast, an excessive dose of an anti-ChE drug results in a cholinergic crisis.

The weakness resulting from cholinergic crisis may resemble myasthenic weakness.

The distinction is made with the edrophonium test.

  • Initially, 2 mg is administered; if improvements of symptoms do not occur within 45 seconds, an additional 8 mg can be administered.
  • Improvement of strength without lingual fasciculations (generally present in non-myasthenics) is a positive test for myasthenia gravis.

Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: The longest cutaneous nerve in the body is ________.
questions.solution:
Saphenous branch of the femoral nerve (saphenous nerve) is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body. It runs along with great saphenous vein in front of medial malleolus and supplies the skin of antero-medial aspect of leg and medial border of foot. Therefore, femoral nerve damage can cause sensory loss over the area of great saphenous vein in leg.

Saphenous nerve may be damaged in front of the medial malleolus during venesection of long saphenous vein. The nerve may also get entrapped as it leaves the adductor canal.

Sciatic nerve is the thickest nerve in the body.

questions.text: LDH flip seen in myocardial infarction is _______.
questions.solution:
LDH flip seen in myocardial infarction is LDH1/LDH2 greater than 1.

Normally, the LDH1/LDH2 ratio is 0.45-0.75, while in MI, it increases.

Flipping effect:

  • Usually, LDH 2 in predominant in serum and LDH 1 is predominant in the heart.
  • Higher levels of LDH 1 than LDH 2 (flipped pattern) is suggestive of myocardial infarction.
  • Damaged cardiac tissues release LDH 1 into the bloodstream.

LDH: A tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits.

  • 4 Subunits with 2 isoforms: H isoform (Heart) and M isoform (Muscle)
  • Heart and RBCs: LDH-1
  • Reticuloendothelial system: LDH-2 
  • Lungs: LDH-3 
  • Kidneys, placenta, and pancreas: LDH-4
  • Liver and striated muscle: LDH-5

questions.text: Blue diaper syndrome is due to malabsorption of ___________
questions.solution:
Blue diaper syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by tryptophan malabsorption. It is also known as Drummond syndrome. The unabsorbed tryptophan is converted to indicans by intestinal bacteria and excreted in the urine. The excreted indicans are oxidized to indigo blue which is responsible for the bluish discoloration of diapers seen in this syndrome.

Other features include

  • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Ocular abnormalities
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Vomiting
  • Constipation
  • Loss of appetite
  • Failure to thrive

questions.text: All of the following are included in Phemister’s triad except _______.
questions.solution:
Phemister’s triad is an X-ray finding in tuberculosis of the hip. It includes

  • Juxta articular osteopenia
  • Reduced joint space
  • Peri articular erosions

questions.text: Change not seen in compression of the cervical sympathetic chain is _____________
questions.solution: Lacrimation is not affected in compression of the cervical sympathetic chain. Ipsilateral mydriasis is seen initially due to irritation of the sympathetic pupillomotor fibers. Later, the sympathetic fibers become paralyzed and Horner’s syndrome characterized by miosis, partial ptosis, hemifacial anhidrosis, and enophthalmos develops.

questions.text: A stool sample of a person suffering from rice-water diarrhea is stained and observed under the microscope, which shows the following image. Which of the following is a selective medium for the growth of the organism shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette consisting of watery stools and the image showing the characteristic fish-in-stream appearance is suggestive of Vibrio cholerae for which Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile-Sucrose agar is the selective medium.

Selective media contain an inhibiting substance that is added to a solid medium. This inhibits the growth of commensals and favors the growth of the required bacterium. 

Vibrio cholerae is aerobic, with scanty slow growth anaerobically. Growth is better in an alkaline medium. NaCl in 0.5–1% concentration is required for optimum growth.

Vibrio colonies can be identified by the string test. A loopful of the growth is mixed with sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. If the test is positive, the suspension loses its turbidity and forms a string when the loop is slowly pulled away from the suspension.

V. cholerae causes a diarrheal disease called cholera. It presents as profuse, painless, watery diarrhea, and vomiting. The pathogenesis involves the production of the cholera toxin which attaches to GM-1 ganglioside receptors on the jejunal epithelium cells.

Option A: Thayer-Martin medium selectively favours the growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with vancomycin, gram-negative organisms with colistin, and fungi with nystatin.

The following image shows the Thayer-Martin medium.

Option C: Lowenstein-Jensen medium is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture. The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein-Jenson medium a selective medium by inhibiting other bacteria. 

The following image shows the Lowenstein-Jenson medium.

Option D: Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan (VR) medium is the transport medium for Vibrio species prepared with crude sea salt and peptone in one liter of distilled water and pH in the range of 8.6 - 8.8. In this medium, vibrios do not multiply but are viable for several weeks.

questions.text:
A neonate is brought to the pediatric emergency. He is weak, hypotonic, flaccid with absent reflexes. His EEG shows burst suppression. What is the stage of hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE)?

EEG - electroencephalogram

choices.text: Sarnat staging is not applicable in this case

questions.solution:
A weak, hypotonic, flaccid baby with absent reflexes and burst suppression on electroencephalogram are findings seen in Sarnat Stage 3 of hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE).

Sarnat Staging of hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE):

questions.text: Cranial nerves are a part of ______.
questions.solution:
Cranial nerves are a part of peripheral nervous system (PNS).

The PNS is composed mainly of spinal nerves, cranial nerves, their ganglia and their ramifications that carry afferent and efferent neurons between the CNS and the rest of the body.

It also includes the peripheral part of the autonomic nervous system, notably the sympathetic trunks and ganglia, and the enteric nervous system, composed of plexuses of nerve fibers and cell bodies in the wall of the gastrointestinal tract.

NOTE: Though there is a contradiction of facts about optic nerve whether it is part of CNS or PNS due to the embryological development, Both Gray’s and Snell’s agree that all cranial nerves are a part of PNS. Hence Option B is the best answer amongst all

questions.text: Fishy odor of the fibroid is seen in ___________________
questions.solution: Red degeneration of fibroid is associated with a peculiar fishy odor. This is due to the release of fatty acids from necrotic muscle cells.

questions.text: Stemmer’s sign is due to ________.
questions.solution:
• Stemmer’s sign is seen in lymphedema.
  • Skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched due to subcutaneous fibrosis.
  • This is called Stemmer’s sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is synthesized by DNA primase during replication?
questions.solution:
DNA primase synthesizes RNA primers during replication of DNA.

During DNA replication, DNA is synthesized using an ssDNA template. This is done by DNA polymerases in the 5' to 3' direction. However, DNA polymerases require an RNA primer, which is a short (10 - 200bp) double stranded region consisting of RNA paired to the DNA templete. Thus, RNA primers serve as scaffolds to which deoxyribonucleotides are added. The RNA in the primers is later replaced by DNA.

Other options:

Option C: Okazaki fragments are lagging strands built on RNA primers by DNA polymerase δ.

Option D: Leading strands are synthesized by DNA polymerase ε.

questions.text: An occasional hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions can occur in patients with psoriasis. It is known as:
questions.solution:
A hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions may occasionally be seen and is known as Woronoff ring.

It is usually associated with treatment, most commonly UV radiation or topical corticosteroids.

The pathogenesis of the Woronoff ring is not well understood but may result from inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis.

Halo dermatitis is the occurrence of an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic nevus.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in benign hypertension?
questions.solution:
Hyaline arteriosclerosis is the morphological picture seen in benign hypertension.

It is characterized by arterioles that are homogenous and show pink hyaline thickening with associated luminal narrowing. It is due to the leakage of plasma proteins in response to the chronic hemodynamic pressures of hypertension.

Malignant hypertension shows the following changes: hyperplastic arteriosclerosis (option A), onion skin appearance due to the concentric and laminated arrangement of the vessels, fibrinoid deposits (option D), and vessel wall necrosis, which are referred to as necrotizing arteriolitis.

Note: The histologic feature seen in pulmonary hypertension ranges from thickening of fibrotic intima to hyperplasia of media. These changes are appreciable in the arterioles of the affected lungs.

The below histopathologic image shows the arteriolar changes in benign hypertension.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about expected frequency (EF) in Chi-square test.

choices.text: It is the frequency that is expected when the null hypothesis is true
Chi square test can be used only if all EF values are >5 in a 2 x 2 table
For 3 x 3 tables, at least 20% of the EF values have to be <5
If observed frequency is equal to expected frequency, null hypothesis is true

questions.solution:
For tables greater than 2 x 2, not more than 20% of the expected frequency values should be <5. Otherwise, the Chi-square test is not valid.

Expected frequency is defined as the frequency one would find when the null hypothesis is true.

This can be understood with an example:


 Drug A Drug B Total
Patients cured 12 4 16
Patients uncured 8 16 24
Total 20 20 40

In the table, you can see two drugs being compared. Let’s find the expected frequency for patients cured using drug A.

Assume the null hypothesis is true. This would mean drugs A and B have the same cure rate.

In this example, since 16 out of 40 people got cured, the cure rate is 16/40.

The expected cure frequency for drug A users is calculated as follows

Expected cure frequency =   cure rate x no of patients using drug A

= (16/40) x 20

= 8

You can see that the expected cure frequency of 8 is different from the observed cure frequency of 12.

Likewise, observed drug B cure frequency is 4 against an expected frequency of 8.

These differences are used in calculating the Chi-square test statistic and rejecting the null hypothesis

 

If there is no difference between the observed and expected frequency, the Chi square test statistic has a value of zero and the null hypothesis is true.

For 2 x 2 tables, the expected frequency values must be >5 for the Chi-square test to be applied.

For tables greater than 2 x 2, the expected frequency must be > 1 for all variables and not more than 20% of the variables should be < 5.

questions.text: Shift of mediastinum to the right due to disease in the right hemithorax is caused by _______.
questions.solution:
Shift of mediastinum to the right due to disease in right hemithorax is caused by collapse of lung.

Shift of mediastinum to same side of lesion-Collapse, consolidation, fibrosis.

Shift of mediastinum to opposite side of lesion-Effusion, mass.

questions.text: The cardiac jelly formed around the heart tube during early development, contributes to the formation of:
questions.solution:
The cardiac jelly is a gelatinous substance present between the endocardium and myocardium of the embryonic heart that transforms into the connective tissue of the endocardium.

Cardiac jelly:

  • The extracellular matrix of the heart or the cardiac jelly is secreted by myocardium.
  • It promotes occlusion of the endocardial tubular lumen during myocardial contraction.
  • It has been called a gelatinoreticulum, a myoepicardial reticulum and, more recently, the myocardial basement membrane.
  • It is composed of hyaluronic acid, hyaluronidase and fibronectin, among other things.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the deformity shown?

choices.text: Little finger is the most commonly involved
It is more common in males
Fasciectomy with skin grafting is done in cases with recurrence
May be associated with Ledderhose and Peyronie’s disease

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Dupuytren’s contracture. The ring finger is most commonly involved.

Dupuytren's contracture is due to the proliferation of previously normal subcutaneous palmar and digital tissues manifesting as nodules and cords that may affect hand function by causing finer and thumb joint flexion contractures.

The contracture begins with increased fibroblast proliferation followed by type III collagen deposition resulting in uncontrolled palmar fascia growth ultimately causing flexion contractures.

The distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) are not involved. The metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are involved. The order of involvement of fingers - ring finger > little finger > middle finger > index finger > thumb.

It is more common in males and the incidence is higher in patients with cirrhosis of the liver, diabetes, smoking, and AIDS. It is also associated with vibration exposure to the wrist and hand. The contractures are usually limited to the medial 3 fingers.

Dupuytren contractures may be associated with similar ectopic lesions in the medial plantar fascia of one or both feet (Ledderhose disease), as plastic penile induration (Peyronie disease), and knuckle pads (Garrod nodules) may present over the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints dorsally.

Treatment:

  • Observation- observation at every three months interval for mild deformities.
  • Radiotherapy- is given only during the early fibroblastic phase.
  • Surgery- is the best-known treatment and is delayed until actual contractures develop. The various procedures performed are:
    • Subcutaneous fasciotomy- preferred in elderly arthritic patients
    • Partial selective fasciotomy- indicated only when the ulnar two fingers are involved
    • Complete fasciectomy- rarely done
    • Fasciectomy with skin grafting- done in young people with epilepsy, alcoholism, and in cases of recurrence after excision
    • Amputation- considered if flexion contractures of PIP joint are very severe
    • Resection and arthrodesis- done for severe contractures of the PIP joint. It is better than amputation as it prevents amputation neuroma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new minor Jones criteria in high risk population according to American Heart Association and World Heart Federation 2015 criteria?
questions.solution:
Monoarthralgia is a new minor Jones criterion in moderate-high risk population.

Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*

Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia

ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion)

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: Katz Wachtel phenomenon is seen in
questions.solution:
Katz Wachtel phenomenon is seen in VSD.

In VSD, there may be signs of both LVH and RVH on the same ECG-e.g. positive diagnostic criteria for LVH with some additional features suggestive of RVH.

questions.text: Which of the following does not suggest a diagnosis of septate uterus?

choices.text: Absence of sagittal notching on USG

questions.solution:
The absence of the uterine fundus makes a septate uterus less likely and is suggestive of a bicornuate uterus.

Septate uterus is associated with the following findings:

  • Absence of sagittal notching on ultrasonography
  • Inter-cornual distance < 4 cm on ultrasonography
  • Angle of divergence between uterine cavities ≤ 75° on hysterosalpingography
  • Presence of uterine fundus seen on laparoscopy or in an MRI scan
  • The fundal midpoint is more than 5 mm above the line joining the ostia of the fallopian tubes

The absence of these findings with an angle of divergence ≥105° makes a bicornuate uterus more likely. An absent uterine fundus would also be suggestive of a bicornuate uterus.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

  • Abortions

  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty

  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

Porto-systemic shunt is not seen in the spleen.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida in her third trimester is brought to the ER in an altered state of consciousness. Lab tests reveal elevated AST, ALT, and bilirubin, while a liver biopsy shows microvesicular fatty infiltration. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The mother has acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP), which is associated with long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl CoA dehydrogenase (3-LCHAD) deficiency. This enzyme is involved in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids.

Women who develop AFLP have heterozygous mutations in the recessive gene for 3-LCHAD. The beta-oxidation capacity is reduced, but patients are asymptomatic outside pregnancy. AFLP develops when such women become pregnant with a fetus homozygous for the 3-LHCAD mutation. The fetus is unable to oxidize fatty acids, which then enter the maternal circulation. These fatty acids overwhelm the maternal oxidation capacity and cause acute fatty liver of pregnancy.

Liver function tests such as AST, ALT, and serum bilirubin levels are raised. Biopsy reveals a characteristic microvesicular fatty infiltration. Fulminant liver failure can lead to hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.text: The type of speech seen in peritonsillar abscess is _______
questions.solution:
Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy. 

 

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. 

Clinical features: 

  • Sore throat/ Dysphagia 
  • Drooling of saliva 
  • Trismus 
  • Ipsilateral otalgia 
  • Fever 

Management: Antibiotics and Incision & Drainage to drain the abscess followed by Interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly matched?

choices.text: Omapatrilat-Inhibits both vasopeptidase as well as angiotensin converting enzyme

questions.solution:
Levosimendan-It is myofilament calcium sensitizer. It's an intravenous positive inotrope used in the treatment of heart failure.

Calcium sensitizers increase the sensitivity of contractile myofilaments to calcium by binding and inducing a conformational change in thin-filament regulatory protein troponin C. The result is increased force of contraction for a given cytosolic calcium concentration.

Racecadotril an encephalinase inhibitor is indicated for symptomatic treatment of diarrhea in infants and children.

Omapatrilat is a dual ACE and vasopeptidase inhibitor that failed clinical trials due to increased risk of angioedema.

Ecadotril is a selective neprilysin inhibitor.

questions.text: The contraceptives with the lowest typical use failure rate are __________________
questions.solution:
Subdermal implants have the lowest typical use failure rate. These include etonorgestrel implants such as Nexplanon and Implanon and levonorgestrel implants such as Norplant and Jadelle.

Intrauterine contraceptive devices are also first tier contraceptives but are not as effective as implants in preventing conception.

Combined oral pills are second tier contraceptives with higher failure rates than implants, IUDs and injectables.

Note: Typical use failure rate is the risk of contraception failure seen in reality. It depends on effectiveness of the contraceptive as well as compliance and use of proper technique.  It is different from theoretical failure rates which assume perfect use by people.

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

questions.text: Doderlein’s bacilli are present in the vagina in all of the following groups except _________
questions.solution:
Lactobacillus acidophilus is called Doderlein’s bacillus and it is not seen in the vagina in toddlers. These bacilli depend on glycogen in the vaginal epithelium for their growth, which is regulated by oestrogen. They ferment the glycogen into lactic acid and lower the vaginal pH. 

In neonates up to 2 weeks of age, maternal oestrogen maintains vaginal glycogen content and Doderlein’s bacilli are present. The bacilli then disappear and reappear at puberty when the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis is activated and oestrogen levels rise. They again disappear in menopause with dropping levels of oestrogen.

questions.text: Asteroid bodies are seen in?
questions.solution:
Asteroid body is seen in Sporotrichosis.

It consists of a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating extensions of eosinophilic material, which are depositions of antigen-antibody complex.

Sporotrichosis or rose gardener’s disease: 

  • It is caused by dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. 
  • Most commonly follows minor trauma like thorn prick etc in rose gardeners, forest workers, etc. 

Clinical features: 

  • Spreads along lymphatics to lymph nodes which become enlarged, suppurative and indurated. 
  • Other rare types – osteoarticular, pulmonary, disseminated type. 

Diagnosis:  

  • Cigar-shaped asteroid bodies in H&E stained tissue sections.  
  • Culture – flower-like clusters of small conidia.
  • Latex agglutination test 
  • Skin test – delayed hypersensitivity to sporotrichin. 

Treatment: 

  • Cutaneous form – Potassium iodide oral or topical 
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole 
  • Disseminated infection – Amphotericin B

questions.text: A female patient comes to you with complaints of midline neck swelling. You proceed to perform the thyroid examination and ask her to swallow. The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia?

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. Pretracheal fascia is attached to the larynx and this attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

The ligament of Berry, also called the suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. It is formed by the condensation of the pre-tracheal fascia. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

Investing layer - It forms the roof of the posterior triangle and splits to enclose:

  • Parotid gland
  • Submandibular gland

Pretracheal fascia - It splits to enclose the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms the suspensory ligament which is known as the ligament of Berry.

Carotid sheath - is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve 

Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Buccopharyngeal fascia - It covers the outer surface of the pharyngeal constrictors and the buccinator. Posteriorly, it's separated from the prevertebral fascia by the retropharyngeal space.

Pharyngobasilar fascia - It fills the gap between superior constrictor and base of the skull.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a patient of generalized tonic clonic seizure?
questions.solution:
Aura is not seen in generalized tonic-clonic seizure.

Generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

  • Onset is abrupt, most often with a loss of consciousness and generalized tonic contraction.
  • Does not have an aura but may be preceded by a prodrome (vague sense seizure will occur).
  • The tonic phase includes asymmetrical movements such as versive head turning, epileptic cry, upward eye deviation with eyes half open and mouth open.
  • Tonic phase gradually evolves to clonic phase; transition can be with high frequency and low amplitude motion known as the vibratory phase.
  • Postictal state individual is limp and unresponsive,snoring is present, its followed by sleep with or without post-ictal confusion. Tongue biting, incontinence of urine or stool may also occur.
  • After awakening, patients have a headache and generalized muscle soreness. The seizures rarely last more than 2 min.
  • Lamotrigine is the first-line agent used in the treatment.

questions.text: All are true regarding the use of sodium fluoride in otosclerosis except _______.

choices.text: It inhibits proteolytic enzymes in the cochlea
Its use is contraindicated in patients with chronic nephritis
It acts by inhibition of osteoblastic activity
It is used in patients with positive Schwartz sign

questions.solution:
Sodium fluoride promotes osteoblastic activity and inhibits osteoclastic activity.

Use of sodium fluride in otosclerosis:

Mechanism of action

  • Sodium fluoride promotes osteoblastic activity and inhibits osteoclastic activity
  • This helps to decrease the bone remodelling taking place in the otosclerotic lesions and promotes recalcification
  • It also inhibits proteolytic enzymes in the cochlea and helps prevent sensorineural deafness

Indications

  • Progressive sensorineural hearing loss
  • Radiological evidence of a lesion
  • Positive Schwartz sign

Contraindications

  • Pregnancy/lactation
  • Fluoride allergy
  • Skeletal fluorosis
  • Children before completion of skeletal growth
  • Chronic rheumatoid arthritis
  • Chronic nephritis

questions.text: When insulin is rapidly infused in a patient, it may lead to __
questions.solution:
When insulin is rapidly infused in a patient, it may lead to hypokalemia.

  •   Insulin infusion results in lowering of the extracellular K+ concentration.
  • Insulin increases the activity of Na, K ATPase in cell membranes so that more K+ is pumped into cells. 
  • Infusions of insulin and glucose significantly lower the plasma K+ level in normal individuals and are very effective for the temporary relief of hyperkalemia in patients with renal failure.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: A 72-year-old male patient complains of headaches. His son adds that the patient also has memory disturbances. Further questioning revealed a history of a fall a few months back. The most probable diagnosis among the following is
questions.solution:
An elderly male patient with a history of memory disturbances and headaches following a history of fall point toward chronic subdural hemorrhage (SDH). 

Chronic SDH is commonly seen in elderly patients. It is also a common cause of acute neurological deterioration in them. Cerebral atrophy in the elderly age group results in the stretching of cortical–dural bridging veins, which makes them vulnerable to rupture. The resulting hematoma can expand over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately leading to symptoms of raised ICP or focal deficits.

There is usually a history of a recent injury. Even apparently trivial impacts may be responsible for this condition, especially if on antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications.

On head CT scan, chronic SDH appears as a hypodense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion as shown in the image below.

Burr hole evacuation is the preferred treatment in most patients with chronic SDH. Conservative treatment can be considered in small, asymptomatic bleeds.

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH.

On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion as shown in the image below.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Or GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

All other conditions, given as options present with rapid deterioration of neurological signs and symptoms along with a history of high-energy impact injury. Hence, they are ruled out.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of Listeria monocytogenes?

choices.text: Grows well on 5% sheep blood agar
It is short, gram-positive and non-spore forming rod

questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes is a facultative anaerobe as it makes ATP by aerobic respiration if oxygen is present but can-do anaerobic respiration in the absence of oxygen.

It is catalase positive and has a tumbling end-over-end motility at 22–28°C but not at 37°C; the motility test rapidly diﬀerentiates Listeria from diphtheroids that are members of the normal microbiota of the skin.

Listeria is one of the most common cause of meningitis in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Which of the following assisted reproductive techniques eliminates the process of natural selection of sperms?
questions.solution:
Intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) eliminates the process of natural selection of sperms. In normal fertilization, only a competent sperm chosen by natural selection can fuse with the oocyte. But, in ICSI, there is no natural selection and a single sperm is injected into the cytoplasm of the oocyte. The association between this artificial selection and an increased risk of congenital anomalies is controversial.

Zygote intra-fallopian transfer (ZIFT), gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT), and intrauterine insemination (IUI) all involve natural selection of sperms.

 

ICSI is the assisted reproductive technique of choice for male factor infertility.

The clinical presentation, direct immunofluorescence, and lesions show a characteristic net-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis and suprabasal acantholytic blister pointing towards the diagnosis of pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: Auerbach’s ganglia in the muscularis externa contain the autonomic neuron bodies of the type _____.
questions.solution:
Auerbach’s ganglia (myenteric ganglia) in the muscularis externa contain the post-ganglionic para-sympathetic autonomic neuron bodies.

The gut wall is densely innervated by both the enteric nervous system (intrinsic control) and the autonomic nervous system (extrinsic control).

Intrinsic innervation:

The intrinsic innervation of the gut is derived from enteric neurones distributed throughout its wall in thousands of small ganglia, each consisting of neuronal cell bodies supported by enteric glial cells.

The majority of enteric neurones in the wall of the gut are found in two ganglionated plexuses:

  • The most extensive of these is the myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus, which consists of a network of nerve fibres and small ganglia lying between the circular and longitudinal layers of the muscularis externa. It runs in continuity from the oesophagus to the anus.
  • The submucosal (Meissner’s) plexus has outer and inner components, and is present throughout the intestine but absent or minimal in the oesophagus and stomach.

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are present in the skeletal muscle except ______________
questions.solution: Skeletal muscle lacks glucose 6 phosphatase, which catalyzes the final step in gluconeogenesis. Hence, skeletal muscles cannot release free glucose from glycogen and all muscle glycogen stores are utilized locally.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is due to the accumulation of α-synuclein:
questions.solution:
Multiple system atrophy is due to the accumulation of α-synuclein.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is an adult-onset, rare, sporadic, multisystem, rapidly progressive neurodegenerative fatal disease. Loss of cells or degeneration in the striatonigral and olivopontocerebellar structures of the brain and spinal cord is the neuropathological hallmark of MSA.

It is accompanied by glial cytoplasmic inclusion bodies known as α-synuclein inclusions in the oligodendrocyte, which is the characteristic feature of multiple system atrophy

α­-synuclein is a presynaptic neuronal acidic protein and a major component of the Lewy body. When they are present in oligodendrocytes, become more sensitive to oxidative stress and show impaired interaction with the extracellular matrix.

α­-synuclein inclusion is mainly found in MSA and parkinsonism disease. So both diseases are referred to as synucleinopathies.

Clinically MSA is characterized by features of autonomic failures like neurogenic orthostatic hypotension or a neurogenic bladder and either parkinsonism (MSA-p) like tremor/rigidity, or cerebellar syndrome (MSA-c) like loss of muscle coordination/balance.

The below image shows a hot cross bun sign (arrow) due to severe atrophy of pons seen in multiple system atrophy-c.

Other options:

Option A- In amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the inclusions accumulated are   TDP-43, FUS

Options B and C- In progressive supranuclear palsy and corticobasal degeneration, the inclusion accumulated are Tau protein. Tau protein accumulation is not seen in multiple system atrophy.

questions.text: Peritoneal dialysis has following complications except _______.
questions.solution:
Weight loss is not a complication of peritoneal dialysis.

Complications of peritoneal dialysis are-

  1. Peritonitis
  2. Catheter blockage
  3. Weight gain and poor diabetic control (dialysate fluid has high sugar content)
  4. Pleural effusion
  5. Metabolic disturbances: Hypoproteinemia, hyperglycemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding colchicine?

choices.text: Most common dose limiting side effect is diarrhoea
It increases the secretion of chemotactic factors
Used  to suppress acute attacks of gout

questions.solution:
Colchicine decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors.

Colchicine:

  • Acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils, thus reducing the inflammatory response overall.
  • It also inhibits the formation of leukotriene B4.
  • Colchicine, NSAIDs, and glucocorticoids are used to suppress the inflammation in an episode of acute gout..
  • Most common and dose-limiting toxicity is diarrhea.
  • Colchicine must be withdrawn temporarily at the first sign of loose stools

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is incidentally found to have high BP. Laboratory investigations show metabolic alkalosis, and reduced renin and aldosterone levels. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with hypertension, metabolic alkalosis, and reduced renin and aldosterone levels, a diagnosis of Liddle syndrome is the most likely.

Liddle syndrome is due to the autosomal dominant gain of function mutation in the epithelium sodium channel, ENaC, in collecting tubules. It classically causes hypertension in young patients, along with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The disease responds to amiloride but is resistant to spironolactone.

Although the clinical presentation of Liddle syndrome is similar to primary hyperaldosteronism or Conn's syndrome (option D), it is characterized by undetectable aldosterone in the serum due to negative feedback. Hence it is also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism. Note that serum renin is low in both Conn's syndrome and Liddle syndrome.

Bartter syndrome (option A) is an autosomal recessive renal tubular reabsorption defect in Na+/K+/2Cl- channel in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle. It causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis. But BP is usually low to normal. It mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Gitelman syndrome (option C) occurs due to a defect in the Na+-Cl- channel in the distal convoluted tubule. Like Bartter syndrome, the patients present with hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and low to normal BP. However, these patients have hypocalciuria and reduced serum magnesium. Gitelman syndrome mimics chronic use of thiazide diuretics.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: What is the most common sign in uterine rupture during labor?
questions.solution:
Non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern is the most common sign in uterine rupture during labor. Variable deceleration of the fetal heart rate is seen initially which later evolves into late deceleration and bradycardia.

Uterine tenderness, pain, and cessation of contractions are less common findings. Shock appears if there is significant concealed haemorrhage and hypovolemia.

questions.text: The most common infection associated with non-immune hydrops is ________________
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 is the most common infectious cause of hydrops fetalis. It infects fetal erythroid progenitor cells and causes anemia. Severe anemia leads to high output cardiac failure and hydrops fetalis.

Most common aneuploidy associated with hydrops fetalis is 45X – Turner syndrome.

questions.text: According to ACOG guidelines, urine dipstick protein level required for a diagnosis of pre-eclampsia is __________
questions.solution:
Urine dipstick protein value must be at least +2 for a diagnosis of preeclampsia to be made.

Preeclampsia is diagnosed if gestational hypertension is present with any one of the following:

  • Proteinuria: ≥ 300mg in 24hours/0.1gL or
  • Protein: Creatinine ratio is ≥ 0.3 or
  • Urine dipstick protein 2+
  • Thrombocytopenia: < 1 lakh/µl
  • Renal insufficiency:  serum Creatinine > 1.1 or doubling from baseline
  • Liver involvement:  Increase in AST and ALT
  • Cerebral symptoms: Headache, visual disturbances, convulsions
  • Pulmonary edema

Note: ACOG updated the urine dipstick protein cut-off from +1 to +2 in 2019.

questions.text: The deflection marked in the aortic waveform is due to ___________________
questions.solution: The deflection marked in the image is the anacrotic notch caused by the reflected pressure wave. Ventricular systole causes a forward pressure wave in large arteries that rebounds against high resistance vessels creating a reflected pressure wave. This reflected wave augments the peak systolic pressure and also creates a notch in the systolic upswing called the anacrotic notch.

questions.text: The given ECG is suggestive of ______.
questions.solution:
There is depression of the ST segment, decrease in the amplitude of the T wave, and an increase in the amplitude of U waves which occur at the end of the T wave. These are the findings of hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

Hyperkalemia: causes tall peaked T waves with a shortened QT interval; further increase in extracellular potassium leads to progressive lengthening of the PR interval and QRS duration; disappearance of the P wave; and widening of the QRS complex to a sine wave pattern followed by asystole.

Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.

Hypercalcemia: shortening of the QT interval, decrease in the ST segment duration

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding Friedriech ataxia except _______.

choices.text: It is a predominantly autosomal dominant ataxia
It is associated with optic atrophy
Most affected individuals develop pes cavus and kyphoscoliosis.

questions.solution:
Frierdiech ataxia is an autosomal recessive disease.  

Frierdich ataxia

  • It is related to chromosome 9q13.
  • It is an autosomal-recessive disease with progressive ataxia, spasticity, weakness, sensory neuropathy, and cardiomyopathy.
  • Deep tendon reflexes are depressed or absent, but an extensor plantar reflex is typically present.
  • Friedreich ataxia is caused by expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the first intron of a gene on chromosome 9q13 that encodes frataxin.
  • Most affected individuals develop pes cavus and kyphoscoliosis.
  • The accompanying cardiomyopathy is associated with a high incidence of arrhythmias and congestive heart failure, which contributes to the deaths of most affected individuals.
  • Vitamin E therapy and identification of an at-risk person’s genotype, together with appropriate family and genetic counselling, can reduce the incidence in future generations.

questions.text: The following Intravenous pyelogram image shows ______.
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelogram (IVP) shows:

  • Ectatic distal collecting ducts contain the microcalcification, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. (option A)
  • Dilated contrast filled tubules within the renal medulla that is known as paintbrush appearance. (option B)

These findings are characteristic for medullary sponge kidney (MSK) on intravenous pyelogram.

Medullary sponge kidney represents a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

questions.text: Canrenone is a metabolite
questions.solution:
Canrenone is a metabolite of spironolactone.

Spironolactone is metabolized in the liver. It is also converted to an active metabolite, canrenone that is responsible for more than 50% of the spironolactone's action.

Spironolactone has a half-life of 1-2 hours while canrenone has a half-life around 18 hours.

Eplerenone, an aldosterone receptor antagonist similar to spironolactone is metabolized primarily by CYP3A4; however, no active metabolites have been identified in human plasma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common plasma cell dyscrasia?
questions.solution:
Monoclonal gammopathy of uncertain significance (MGUS) is the most common plasma cell dyscrasia.

The patients are asymptomatic and serum M protein levels are less than 3gm/dL.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants

questions.solution:
Lymphoma is the most common cause of neoplastic enlargement of the spleen.

The most common primary tumor of the spleen is hemangioma.

questions.text: False statement regarding liraglutide is _________.

choices.text: It is a GLP-1 receptor agonist
It reduces post meal hyperglycemia by increasing glucose mediated insulin release

questions.solution:
Liraglutide promotes weight loss.

Liraglutide is a soluble fatty acid-acylated GLP-1 analog. The half-life is approximately 12 hours, permitting once-daily dosing. It is approved in patients with type 2 diabetes who achieve inadequate control with diet and exercise and are receiving concurrent treatment with metformin, sulfonylureas, or thiazolidinediones.

It reduces post-meal hyperglycemia by:

  • Increasing glucose mediated insulin release
  • Lowering glucagon levels
  • Slowing gastric emptying
  • Decreasing appetite

It is used in type 2 DM and is the only GLP-1 receptor agonist used in obesity.

NOTE:

GLP-1 analogs, pramlintide, SGLT-2 inhibitors, and metformin* cause weight loss.

DPP-4 inhibitors and alpha-glucosidase inhibitors are weight neutral drugs.

Sulfonylureas and insulin promote weight gain.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about apoptosis?

choices.text: Mitochondrial pathway acts by release of cytochrome C
Bax and Bak are antiapoptotic in nature
Extrinsic pathway involves type 1 TNF and CD95
Both pathways act by activation of caspases

questions.solution:
Bax and Bak are proapoptotic in nature and are held in control by Bcl-2 to prevent apoptosis in normal cell.

Apoptosis has two pathways:

a. Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway:

Cell injury results in release of cytochrome C and other pro-apoptotic proteins from mitochondria.

These then activate caspase 9 which cause nuclear fragmentation and formation of apoptotic bodies.

b. Death receptor or extrinsic pathway:

In this pathway activation of death receptors cause apoptosis, [prototypic death receptors are the type I TNF receptor and Fas (CD95)] by activating caspase-8.

questions.text: Pain sensation from the ethmoid sinus is carried via?
questions.solution:
Pain sensation from the ethmoid sinus is carried by the posterior ethmoidal branch of the nasociliary nerve.

Nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. 

The other branches of the nasociliary nerve are

  • Long ciliary nerves
  • Infratrochlear nerve
  • Communicating branch to the ciliary ganglion (long root of the ciliary ganglion)

Other options:

Frontal nerve carries sensations from the forehead, frontal sinus mucosa, and the upper eyelid. It has 2 branches—supraorbital nerve and supratrochlear nerve.

Lacrimal nerve innervates the lacrimal gland, conjunctiva, and the lateral upper eyelids.

questions.text: All of the following changes are seen in RBCs during storage of whole blood except ___________
questions.solution:
There is a loss of intracellular potassium during storage of RBCs.

Other changes include the following:

  • Increase in intracellular sodium
  • Spheroechinocytosis - RBCs become spherical with surface projections
  • Loss of membrane lipids and proteins
  • Decrease in pH
  • Decrease in 2,3 DPG
  • Depletion of ATP and other nucleotides

Except severe membrane changes, all other changes are reversible. The viability of the transfused RBCs correlates with the degree of membrane damage.

questions.text: The positive finding shown in the image below is seen with?
questions.solution:
The image shows Tzanck cells which are multinucleated giant cells and is commonly seen in infection with Herpes simplex virus.

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

Immunobullous Disorders 
Pemphigus Vulgaris Multiple acantholytic cells (Tzanck cells)
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with very few inflammatory cells
Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis(TEN) Necrotizing or degenerating basal cells with scattered inflammatory cells and fibroblasts 
Bullous pemphigoid (BP), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and erosive lichen planus No acantholytic cells ; Many leucocytes
Cutaneous Infections 
Herpes simplex, varicella, herpes zoster Ballooning degeneration and multinucleated giant cells are seen
Molluscum contagiosum Diagnostic intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 microns)
Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola Acantholytic squamous keratinocytes , eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion called a "Guarnieri body"
 Leishmaniasis Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodiesgrouped together in a typical "swarm of bees" fashion, within large macrophages (Wright's cells)
Bullous Impetigo Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with abundant neutrophils and clusters of coccoid bacteria
Genodermatoses 
Hailey-Hailey disease Multiple acantholytic cells; Direct Immunofluorescence Negative
Darier's Disease "Corps ronds" are isolated keratinocytes with a round shape and an acidophilic cytoplasm. The corps grains are seen as small, hyaline, acidophilic ovoid bodies resembling pomegranate seeds.
Cutaneous Tumours 
Squamous Cell Carcinoma Atypical Squamous Cells
Basal Cell Carcinoma Clusters of Basaloid cells

 

Image : Tzanck smear , showing three multinucleated giant cells in center.

questions.text: The given logo belongs to which of the following programmes?

choices.text: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the National Programme for Prevention & Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NP-NCD), which was earlier called the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

NPCDCS was launched in 2010 in order to prevent and control major NCDs (non-communicable diseases). It focuses on strengthening infrastructure, human resource development, health promotion, early diagnosis, management, and referral. NCD Clinics are being set up at District and CHC levels, to provide services for early diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up for common NCD. NP-NCD has specialized facilities at the district hospital level. At the subcentre level, screening and referral are done.

The NP-NCD has separate components for cancer and other non-communicable diseases like diabetes, and stroke. It has been implemented in over 100 districts in 21 states. For the cancer component, there is the Tertiary Care Cancer Centers (TCCC) scheme, which aims at setting up/strengthening State Cancer Institutes (SCI) and TCCCs all over the country, to provide comprehensive cancer care in the country. 

Note: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has been integrated with this programme in 2021.

Other options:

Option A: The logo below shows Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram

Option C: The logo below shows Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission

Option D: The logo below shows Family Planning Campaign

questions.text: The incision used in endomeatal approach to the ear is?
questions.solution:
Rosen’s incision is used in endomeatal approach to the middle ear.

Endomeatal approach: It is used to raise tympanomeatal flap is order to expose the middle ear. Rosen’s incision is most commonly used in the endomeatal approach for stapedectomy. It is also used for exploratory tympanotomy to find the cause of conductive hearing loss.

Other options:

Lempert I and II incision: Used in Endaural approach

Wilde’s incision: Postaural approach

questions.text: All are seen in Bernard - Horner’s syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Enophthalmos (sunken globe) is seen in Bernard-Horner’s syndrome and not exophthalmos.

Any condition or injury that destroys the sympathetic trunk ascending from the thorax through the neck into the face results in Horner’s syndrome.

Horner’s syndrome is characterized by

  • Ptosis
  • Miosis
  • Enophthalmos
  • Anhidrosis

Special features of congenital Horner’s syndrome are:

  • Iris heterochromia (due to lack of sympathetic stimulation during development)
  • Unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about rheumatic fever?

choices.text: Erythema Marginatum of acute rheumatic fever(ARF) involves whole body
Subcutaneous nodules are small,painful bumps beneath the skin

questions.solution:
The true statement is IVIg given in refractory cases:

Sydenham’s chorea

  • It follows a prolonged latent period (3-6 months) after group A streptococcal infection.
  • The choreiform movements affect particularly the head (causing characteristic darting movements of the tongue) and the upper limbs. It mainly affects females.

    Erythema Marginatum

  • Is a classic rash of ARF. It begins as pink maculesthat clear centrally, leaving a serpiginous, spreading edge.
  • The rash is evanescent, appearing and disappearing before the examiner’s eyes. It occurs usually on the trunk, sometimes on the limbs, but almost never on the face.

Subcutaneous nodules 

  • Occur as painless, small (0.5–2 cm), mobile lumps beneath the skin overlying bony prominences, particularly of the hands, feet, elbows, occiput and occasionally the vertebrae.
  • It is commonly associated with carditis

Treatment is sedatives and valproate. In refractory cases IVIg is given.

questions.text: Which among the following is a waxy, luminous & translucent poison?
questions.solution:
Yellow phosphorous (white phosphorous) is a waxy & translucent material which becomes luminous in the dark.

It has garlicky odor and taste. On exposure to air, oxidizes and emits white fumes, ignites at 34°C.

Use: Fertilizers, vermin-killers, rodenticide, fireworks, gunpowder.

It is highly toxic.

Other options:

Cobra venom is a transparent yellow viscous liquid.

Iodine is a bluish-black solid which sublimate into a noxious violet-pink gas.

questions.text: The most common mediastinal tumor is _______.
questions.solution:
The most common mediastinal tumors in descending order of incidence are thymoma (25%), germ cell tumor (13%), lymphoma, mesenchymal, and thyroid.

The Masaoka classification and TNM staging are used in the staging of thymoma.

The most common mediastinal tumor in children is the neurogenic tumor.

Anterior Mediastinum

questions.text: A cytokine that activates cells to express MHC class II antigens and protects cells from virus replication is
questions.solution:
Interferon-γ activates cells to express MHC class I and II antigens, activates macrophages, and is also anti-viral.

Other option:

  • Interferon-α activates only MHC class I, NK cell, and macrophages and is also anti-viral.
  • IL-6 causes B cell stimulation and is a mediator of acute phase reactions.
  • TNF-α activates macrophages and cytotoxic cells and also induces cachexia and cytokines such a IL-6 and IL-1.

questions.text: Which of the following increases in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Inspiratory capacity increases in pregnancy.  The increase is due to a greater downward excursion of the diaphragm that’s pushed up by the gravid uterus. This raises the tidal volume and, in turn, the inspiratory capacity that's made up of tidal volume plus inspiratory reserve volume. 

Increases Decreases Unaffected
Tidal volume Functional residual capacity Respiratory rate
Inspiratory capacity Expiratory reserve volume Vital capacity
Minute O2 uptake Residual volume Inspiratory reserve volume
Minute ventilation Total lung capacity (either decreased or unaffected)

questions.text: The brick red color of post-mortem lividity is seen in poisoning due to ______.
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a monozygotic twin pregnancy is found to have discordant twins and undergoes an umbilical artery doppler test. What finding in the smaller twin is associated with the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Persistently absent end-diastolic flow has the worst prognosis.

Based on the umbilical artery doppler findings in the smaller fetus, discordant monochorionic twin pregnancies are classified into three types:

Type Doppler finding Prognosis
I Positive end-diastolic flow Best
II Persistently absent end-diastolic flow Worst
III Intermittently absent/intermittently reversed end-diastolic flow Intermediate

Intermittently absent/intermittently reversed end-diastolic flows are due to arterio-arterial anastomoses between the umbilical arteries of the discordant fetuses. It has a better prognosis than persistently absent flow.

questions.text: Split skin graft survives by the process of plasma imbibition till which time period?
questions.solution:
Split skin graft survives by the process of plasma imbibition till 48hrs following transplantation surgery.

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hrs because of imbibition of plasma from wound bed.
  • After 48 hrs, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to inosculation of blood.
  • Revascularization is the process by which new blood vessels directly invade the graft and restore the pink hue of the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true?

choices.text: Tennis elbow is an inflammation of common extensor origin from the lateral epicondyle mainly extensor carpi radialis brevis
Tennis leg is tear of lateral head of gastrocnemius
Tennis fracture is avulsion fracture of tuberosity of 5th metatarsal
Tennis racket cells (on electron microscopy) are hallmark of Langerhans cell histiocytosis

questions.solution:
Tennis leg is rupture of the medial head of gastrocnemius.

Tennis elbow also called as lateral epicondylitis, is an inflammation of common extensor origin from the lateral epicondyle mainly extensor carpi radialis brevis.

Tennis fracture is avulsion fracture of tuberosity of the 5th metatarsal due to the pull of the peroneus brevis muscle.

Tennis racket cells /Birbeck granules (on electron microscopy) are the hallmark of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Tennis racket cells seen in light microscopy are found in sarcoma botryoides.

 

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the pudendal nerve, except

choices.text: Comes in through the greater sciatic foramen
Main nerve supply of the pelvic organs

questions.solution:
The pudendal nerve is the main nerve supply of the perineum, not the pelvic organs.

It carries both the sensory and motor fibres of the perineum.

The pudendal nerve arises from the ventral divisions of the S2, 3, 4 sacral ventral rami and leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen between piriformis and ischiococcygeus to enter the gluteal region.

It then accompanies the internal pudendal artery through the lesser sciatic foramen into the pudendal (Alcock’s) canal on the lateral wall of the ischio-anal fossa.

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of acromegaly?
questions.solution:
Macroencephaly is not a feature of acromegaly.

Features of Acromegaly

  • Frontal bossing
  • Increased hand and foot size
  • Mandibular enlargement with prognathism
  • Widened space between the lower incisor teeth
  • In children and adolescents - pituitary gigantism
  • Soft tissue swelling
    • Increased heel pad thickness
    • Increased shoe or glove size and ring tightening
    • Characteristic coarse facial features and a large fleshy nose
  • Generalized visceromegaly occurs
  • Cardiovascular system
    • Cardiomyopathy with arrhythmias, left ventricular hypertrophy, decreased diastolic function, and hypertension ultimately occurs in most patients if untreated
  • Upper airway obstruction with sleep apnea
  • Diabetes mellitus develops in 25% of patients (as GH counteracts the action of insulin)
  • Increased risk of colon polyps and mortality from colonic malignancy Other commonly encountered clinical features include hyperhidrosis, a deep and hollow-sounding voice, oily skin, arthropathy, kyphosis, carpal tunnel syndrome, proximal muscle weakness and fatigue, acanthosis nigricans, and skin tags.

In acromegaly there is enlargement of all organs EXCEPT brain. 

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following rectal prolapse procedures is performed through the abdominal approach?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Repstein operation is the abdominal approach for rectal prolapse.

It is managed by using the Perineal approach or the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is easy to perform and has fewer complications but a high recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach for rectal prolapse are the following:

  • Thiersch's wiring
  • Delorme's mucosectomy
  • Altemeier's procedure or perineal recto sigmoidectomy

The abdominal approach is difficult to perform and has more complications but a lower recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach are the following: 

  • Moschcowitz repair
  • Ripstein and Wells rectopexy; ventral rectopexy or suture rectopexy
  • Resection rectopexy

If the patient is fit enough for an abdominal procedure, it is preferred over the perineal procedure, since the risk of recurrence is lower. The perineal approach is preferred in elderly patients with comorbidities and in young men since the abdominal approach may injure the pelvic autonomic nerves which may result in sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: All of the following drugs absorption will be more in the presence of food except?
questions.solution:
Levodopa absorption will not be more in the presence of food.

Ampicillin, Aspirin, Atenolol, Azithromycin, indinavir, isoniazid, rifampin, tetracycline

Drug absorption increased by food:

 Griseofulvin, Fibrates,Albendazole, Protease inhibitors, Carbamazepine, Mefloquine, lithium, hydralazine.

questions.text: The test to determine blood groups in a blood stain is?
questions.solution:
The common blood groups ABO, MNS and Rh systems can be determined in a blood stain by Lattes crust method.

Other options:

  • Luminol spray is used to identify blood stains which are no longer visible due to washing of crime scene.
  • Kastle-Meyer test is used to identify visible blood stains.
  • Haemin crystal test is a micro chemical test, confirmatory test for blood stains.

questions.text: PAO2 is maximum at the ______________
questions.solution:
PAO2 refers to the partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli and is maximum at the apex of lung. This is because the apex has the greatest ventilation-perfusion ratio, resulting in an alveolar oxygen concentration closest to that of inspired air.

PaO2 refers to the partial pressure of oxygen in the arterial blood and this is also maximum at the apex.

questions.text: Orphan Annie eye nuclei is a characteristic feature of:
questions.solution:
Orphan Annie eye nuclei is a characteristic feature of papillary carcinoma of thyroid.

The nuclei of papillary carcinoma cells contain finely dispersed chromatin, which gives a clear appearance called as ground-glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei.

Papillary carcinoma can also contain concentrically calcified structures called as psammoma bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is not seen in Behcet's disease?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is corrected using a base out prism?
questions.solution:
Esophoria and esotropia can be corrected using a base-out prism, after ruling out refractive errors. The prism eliminates diplopia by aligning the images formed in the two eyes.

Exo-deviations are corrected using base-in prisms.

Accommodative esotropia is due to hypermetropia and is corrected with +D spherical lenses.

In regular astigmatism, toric lenses are used.

questions.text: What is the seventh enzyme class as per The International Union of Biochemistry (IUBMB) classification of enzymes?
questions.solution:
Translocases are classified under the seventh enzyme class as per The International Union of Biochemistry (IUBMB) classification of enzymes.

Translocases aid in the transfer of phospholipids like phosphatidylcholine from the inner membrane to the outer membrane. It also catalyzes the translocation of other components like inorganic anions, amino acids, carbohydrates, hydrogen ions, and inorganic cations. 

Related Pearl: Enzyme classification

There are seven groups of enzymes according to IUBMB.

E.C. NO. Enzyme class Type of reaction catalyzed with examples
1 Oxidoreductases

Catalyze redox reactions

  • Dehydrogenase
  • Oxygenase
  • Oxidase
  • Catalase
  • Peroxidase
2 Transferases

Catalyze the transfer of functional groups from one substrate to another.

  • Kinases
  • Transaminases
  • Transmethylases
3 Hydrolases

Catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.

  • Lipase
  • Arginase
  • Pepsin
  • Esterase
4 Lyases

Catalyze the cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, thereby generating double bonds.

  • Aldolase
  • Fumarase
  • HMG-CoA lyase
  • Arginosuccinase
5 Isomerases

Catalyze structural changes within a molecule.

  • Phosphohexoisomerase
  • Mutase
  • Racemase
6 Ligases

Catalyze the joining together of two molecules in reactions.

  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • PRPP synthetase
  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase
  • Glutamine synthetase
7 Translocases Catalyze the movement of molecules or ions across membranes.

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling in the buccal cavity. A biopsy of the tissue was done and the histological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows both epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right), which is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is the most common site. The submandibular and minor salivary glands are the less common sites. They present as painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses within the parotid or submandibular areas or in the buccal cavity.

Gross features- The tumors are rounded and well-demarcated. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

Microscopic features consist of:

  • The epithelial elements- They resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • Mesenchymal elements consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

Other options: 

Option A - Oncocytomas arise from the kidneys. They are epithelial neoplasms that are composed of large eosinophilic cells with small, round, benign-appearing nuclei with large nucleoli. 

 

Option B - Ductal papillomas arise from the ductal epithelium of the breast. They have multiple branching fibrovascular cores with epithelial hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia. The following image shows the histological appearance of ductal papilloma. 

 

Option D - Warthin tumors are benign neoplasms of the parotid gland. They appear as round to oval encapsulated masses. Histologically, they have a dense lymphoid stroma with germinal centers, the spaces are narrowed by polypoid projections of lymphoepithelial elements. The upper later has palisading columnar cells and the lower layer has cuboidal to polygonal cells. The following image shows a Warthin tumor. 

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman comes to you in her first trimester and asks for your advice regarding immunisation. Which of the following vaccines would you tell is contraindicated for her?
questions.solution:
Varicella vaccine is contraindicated for her as she is pregnant.

Varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine which is recommended for children aged 12-18 months and those without a history of chickenpox infection in the past. It is administered subcutaneously in one or two-dose schedules. 

It is contraindicated in pregnant, immunocompromised individuals and those who are allergic to neomycin. However, patients with clinically stable HIV on HAART (highly active anti-retroviral therapy) can be considered for vaccination if CD4+ cells >15%. Avoidance of salicylates is recommended 6 weeks after the vaccination to prevent Reye's syndrome. 

Maternal varicella infection may result in fetal loss and birth defects. If maternal varicella infection occurs within 5 days of delivery, the baby should receive VZIG (varicella-zoster immunoglobulin) due to the risk of disseminated infection.

Other options: 

Options A: Hepatitis A vaccine can be administered as pre-exposure or post-exposure prophylaxis in high-risk pregnant individuals in a two-dose schedule given intramuscularly one month apart.

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine can be administered as pre-exposure or post-exposure prophylaxis in high-risk pregnant individuals. It is given intramuscularly in three doses at 0, 1, and 6 months. 

Option C: Tetanus toxoid is routinely administered in pregnant women. The first dose is given at 16-20 weeks while the second dose is at 20-24 weeks ideally maintaining a one-month interval between the two doses.
