questions.text: Which of the following is true about the weekly iron and folic acid supplementation (WIFS) scheme?

choices.text: Weekly administration of 150mg of elemental iron
Biannual de-worming to control helminthic infection
Weekly administration of  200 μg of folic acid

questions.solution:
Biannual de-worming to control helminthic infection is one of the interventions in the WIFS scheme. All the other options are incorrect.

 

Weekly iron and folic acid supplementation scheme (WIFS) was introduced to curb the high prevalence and incidence of anemia among adolescent boys and girls.

Key interventions:

  • Supervised weekly administration of 100mg of elemental iron and 500 μg of folic acid.
  • Biannual de-worming by the administration of Albendazole 400mg, to control helminth infection.
  • Screening of target groups for moderate/severe anemia and referral to appropriate health facility if needed.
  • Information and Counseling to improve dietary intake and prevent intestinal worm infestation.

 

Note: Anemia Mukt Bharat, is an initiative launched in 2018, to reduce the prevalence of anemia by 3 percentage points every year, among children, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant, and lactating women. The recommended dosage of IFA for adolescent boys and girls under this scheme is 60mg iron + 500 μg folic acid, weekly.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

questions.text: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is due to a defect in:
questions.solution:
Glanzmann thrombasthenia is due to defect in glycoprotein IIb-IIIa, which is causes bridge formation between platelets by binding fibrinogen. This results in bleeding due to defective platelet aggregation.

Bernard-Soulier syndrome is due to the defect in Glycoprotein Ib-IX, which is necessary for platelet adhesion to subendothelial matrix.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to dermatology OPD with the given condition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing hyperpigmented macules on the face is diagnostic of melasma.

Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis and is manifested by hyperpigmented macules on the face which become more pronounced after sun exposure.

Hyper-melanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, chin and mandible region. 

Melasma is more common in women (90%) and in ages between 20-40 years. It is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives.

Melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:

  • Hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity)
  • Kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor)
  • Chemical peels
  • Kligman's triple combination- Topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream [First line]

Other Options:

Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus is characterised by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of the nasolabial folds.

Option C: The same facial melanosis in pregnant women is called Chloasma or mask of pregnancy. Only the terms used differ. Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Chloasma usually resolves after pregnancy.

Option D: Rosacea mainly involves the convexities of the face and presents as erythemato-telangiectatic type over the cheeks.

questions.text: Which joint is not fused in triple arthrodesis done for CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus)?
questions.solution:
The tibio-talar joint is not fused in the triple arthrodesis done for CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus).

Triple arthrodesis consists of fusion of the three joints of the foot:

  • Talo-navicular joint
  • Talo-calcaneal joint 
  • Calcaneo-cuboid joint.

Triple arthrodesis is done after 10-12 years of age when there is complete skeletal maturation.

Before this age bones are not fully ossified, therefore fusion may not be adequate.

Of the three talo-navicular joint fusion is the most difficult to achieve.

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: Which of the following is true about longus coli?
questions.solution:
Longus coli is situated on the anterior surface of vertebral column, between the atlas and third thoracic vertebra. The muscle is broad in the middle, narrow and pointed at either end, and consists of three portions - a superior oblique, inferior oblique and vertical.

Origin: Transverse process of C-5 to T-3

Insertion: Anterior arch of the atlas

Artery: Ascending pharyngeal, inferior thyroid and vertebral arteries

Nerve supply: C2 - C6 (anterior rami)

Actions: Flexes the neck forwards. Its main antagonist is longissimus cervicis.

questions.text: Hyaluronidase participates in the degradation of _____________
questions.solution:
Hyaluronidase participates in the initial degradation of chondroitin sulphate because of its structural similarity with hyaluronic acid.

Note: Though hyaluronidase and heparan sulfate have the same major building blocks, heparan sulfate is insensitive to hyaluronidase. This is because heparan sulfate has other groups as well and the linkage is also different.

questions.text: The audiogram given in the image below is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an upsloping/ ascending audiogram in which lower frequencies are affected first like in the early stages of Meniere's disease also known as endolymphatic hydrops. 

Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system.

Meniere's disease is usually unilateral. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness.

Pure tone audiometry reveals a sensorineural type of hearing loss with lower frequencies affected first. It shows a rising type of curve. As the disease progresses, middle and higher frequencies get involved, and the audiogram becomes flat or downsloping type.

The illustration given below shows an audiogram seen in different stages of Meniere's disease.

Other options:

Option A: Ototoxicity causes bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry shows a downsloping audiogram, typically involving frequencies above 8,000 Hz and progresses to lower speech frequencies. Common drugs causing the same include aminoglycoside antibiotics; loop diuretics (not thiazides); antimalarials; cisplatin; and NSAIDs like ibuprofen, salicylates, and indomethacin.

Option B: Presbycusis is a physiological sensorineural hearing loss occurring in individuals above 65 years of age. Audiometry shows a downsloping graph.

Option C: In noise-induced hearing loss, audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: The antithyroid drug to be used in early gestation is______
questions.solution:
Propylthiouracil should be used in early gestation. 

Because of its rare association with hepatotoxicity, propylthiouracil should be limited for clinical administration to the first trimester and then maternal therapy should be changed to the application of methimazole (or carbimazole) at a ratio of 15–20 mg of propylthiouracil to 1 mg of methimazole.

Other options:

Because of the association of rare cases of Aplasia cutis congenita and other defects, such as choanal atresia with carbimazole and methimazole.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with diabetes presents with complaints of dark floating spots and flashes of light in her left eye. Optical coherence tomography of the left eye is given in the image below. Identify the pathology.
questions.solution:
The image shows vitreomacular traction with detached posterior vitreous membrane and foveal traction. 

OCT images:

1. Normal OCT

 

2. Vitreomacular traction- The fovea is elevated from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), as indicated by the arrow. Pseudocysts and retinal morphology distortion may also be seen at the site of traction.

 

3. Vitreomacular adhesion- posterior vitreous detachment but no macular or foveal traction. The retinal morphology is normal.

 

4. Macular hole - a partial or full-thickness retinal defect is seen.

A full-thickness macular hole is seen in the image below.

 

5. Central serous retinopathy- fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment. 

 

6. Cystoid macular edema - loss of foveal depression with cystoid spaces in the retina.

questions.text: Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) is called a superantigen because:

choices.text: They are able to evade the immune system
They are able to bind to the peptide-binding cleft on MHC molecules
Can cause T cells to be activated non specifically
High dose is required to cause symptoms

questions.solution:
TSST-1 is called a super antigen because they bind outside the peptide-binding cleft on MHC molecules and cause T cells to be activated nonspecifically.

This results in excess production of cytokines and the resulting inflammatory response and shock.

Toxic shock syndrome is caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Toxic shock syndrome is caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST)(enterotoxin F or pyrogenic exotoxin C (MC) followed by Enterotoxin B, C) produced by S. aureus.
  • Clinical Presentation: Fever, hypotension, erythematous rash, and diarrhea.
  • It is common among menstruating women using vaginal tampons. 
  • TSST is an exfoliative toxin and enterotoxin belong to class superantigens,i.e., these act directly on T cell without antigen-presenting cell involvement.
  • Treatment: clindamycin

questions.text: A 51 year old gentleman was being worked up for hepatocellular function. He had no history or signs of hepatic encephalopathy. His serum bilirubin was 5mg%, serum albumin was 3.9gm% and international normalized ratio is 1.6.On ultrasound, no free fluid was detected inside the abdomen. According to Child-Turcotte-Pugh(CTP) classification, he was classified in:
questions.solution:
The Child-Turcotte-Pugh score for the given patient is 7 which is classified as Class B.

The Overall surgical mortality rates for Class B cirrhosis is 30%.

questions.text: Which of the following is not recommended by WHO to decrease cardiovascular diseases?

choices.text: Reduction of salt intake to 5 grams per day or less
Reduction in dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day
Decrease in consumption of complex carbohydrates
Consumption of saturated fats to less than 10% of total energy intake

WHO has recommended to increase the consumption of complex carbohydrates such as whole grains, fruits and vegetables.

questions.text: The combination of alopecia, skin rash, painful peripheral neuropathy and confusion with lethargy are seen in?
questions.solution:
The combination of alopecia & skin rash, painful peripheral neuropathy and confusion with lethargy are known as ‘Thallium triad’.

It is indicative of chronic thallium poisoning.

Other symptoms include:

  • Dystrophy of nails - Mees’ lines (also seen in arsenic poisoning),
  • Cardiovascular symptoms like hypertension and cardiomyopathy,
  • Ophthalmological symptoms like ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, keratitis, lens opacity and optic atrophy.

questions.text: Lumbar hemivertebra results due to the abnormal development of:
questions.solution:
Lumbar hemivertebra results due to the abnormal development of sclerotomes. 

The vertebral column and ribs develop from the sclerotome compartments of the somite. 

As development continues, the sclerotome portion of each somite also undergoes a process called resegmentatíon. Resegmentation occurs when the caudal half of each sclerotome grows into and fuses with the cephalic half of each subjacent sclerotome. 

Thus, each vertebra is formed from the combination of the caudal half of one somite and the cranial half of its neighbor. Note: Patterning of the shapes of the different vertebrae is regulated by HOX genes.
